{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}}
{{Infobox cinema market | name = Cinema of Lebanon | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = City Mall [[Beirut]] | screens = 185 (2009)<ref name=screens_uis>{{cite web|title=Table 8: Cinema Infrastructure – Capacity|url=http://stats.uis.unesco.org/unesco/TableViewer/tableView.aspx?ReportId=5542|publisher=UNESCO Institute for Statistics|accessdate=5 November 2013}}</ref> | screens_per_capita = 4.7 per 100,000 (2009)<ref name=screens_uis/> | distributors = {{br separated entries|Haddad & Co|Italia Film|Fathalla}}<ref name=distributors_uis>{{cite web|title=Table 6: Share of Top 3 distributors (Excel)|url=http://stats.uis.unesco.org/unesco/ReportFolders/reportFolders.aspx|publisher=UNESCO Institute for Statistics|accessdate=5 November 2013}}</ref> | produced_year = 2015 | produced_ref = <ref name=production_uis>{{cite web|title=IDAL Film Industry Fact Book 2015|url=http://investinlebanon.gov.lb/Content/uploads/CorporatePageRubric/180123031720175~Film%20Industry%20factsheet%202015.pdf|publisher=IDAL Film Industry Fact Book 2015|accessdate=31 May 2018}}</ref> | produced_total = 31 | produced_fictional = 17 (56%) | produced_documentary = 14 (42%) | produced_animated = 1 (1%) | produced_musical = 1 (1%) | admissions_year = 2010 | admissions_ref = <ref name=euromedaudiovisuel>{{cite web|title=Country profile: 3. Lebanon|url=http://euromedaudiovisuel.net/Files/2013/08/20/1377006300954.pdf|publisher=Euromed Audiovisual|accessdate=14 November 2013|pages=90–91}}</ref> | admissions_total = 2,794,708 | admissions_national = 16,666 (0.49%) | box_office_year = 2006 | box_office_ref = <ref name=adm_gross_uis>{{cite web|title=Table 11: Exhibition – Admissions & Gross Box Office (GBO)|url=http://stats.uis.unesco.org/unesco/TableViewer/tableView.aspx?ReportId=5538|publisher=UNESCO Institute for Statistics|accessdate=5 November 2013}}</ref> | box_office_total = [[Lebanese Pound|LBP]] {{Format price|48375000}} | box_office_national = LBP {{Format price|2000000}} (4.1%) }} The '''cinema of Lebanon''', according to film critic and historian Roy Armes, is the only other cinema in the Arabic-speaking region, beside Egypt's, that could amount to a national cinema.<ref name="Armes, Roy page 26">Armes, Roy. ''Arab Filmmakers of the Middle East: a Dictionary'', page 26</ref> Cinema in Lebanon has been in existence since the 1920s,{{sfn|Shafik|2007|p=9}} and the country has produced more than 500 films.<ref>Harabi, Najib. ''Knowledge Intensive Industries: Four Case Studies of Creative Industries in Arab Countries'', World Bank Project, 2009, page 16.</ref>
While there has been steady increase in film production since the end of the [[Lebanese Civil War]],<ref>{{cite web|title="IDAL, Film Industry Fact Book 2015"|url=http://investinlebanon.gov.lb/Content/uploads/CorporatePageRubric/180123031720175~Film%20Industry%20factsheet%202015.pdf}}</ref> the number of films produced each year remains relatively small in comparison to what it used to be in the 1960s, and the industry remains heavily dependent on foreign funding, mainly European.<ref>{{cite web|title="Strictly Dabkeh! New Lebanese film 'Bosta' hits town"|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2005/Nov-25/6220-strictly-dabkeh-new-lebanese-film-bosta-hits-town.ashx}}</ref> The industry also remains reliant on international box office revenues due to the limited size of the domestic market.<ref name=amo12/>
Despite that, local films have enjoyed a degree of local and international success. Ziad Doueiry's [[The Insult (film)|''The Insult'']] was nominated for an Academy Award for [[List of submissions to the 90th Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Language Film]].<ref name=amo12>{{cite web|title="Oscar Foreign-Language Race Is a Puzzle as Front-Runners Fall"|url=https://variety.com/2018/film/awards/oscar-foreign-language-race-is-a-puzzle-1202688456/}}</ref> [[Nadine Labaki|Nadine Labaki's]] three features have been screened at the [[Cannes Film Festival]], starting with ''[[Caramel (film)|Caramel]]'' in the Directors’ Fortnight.<ref name="fortnight">{{cite web|url=http://www.quinzaine-realisateurs.com/films/14103/Caramel.html|title=Long Metrage - Caramel|publisher=Quinzaine des Realisateurs|accessdate=29 December 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090515162955/http://www.quinzaine-realisateurs.com/films/14103/Caramel.html|archivedate=15 May 2009|df=}}</ref> Her second feature ''[[Where Do We Go Now?]]'' was screened in [[Un Certain Regard]] and later won the [[Toronto International Film Festival People's Choice Award|People’s Choice Award]] at the [[Toronto International Film Festival]] while her third feature, ''[[Capernaum (film)|Capernaum]]'', was nominated for a [[Palme D'Or]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://deadline.com/2018/05/cannes-2018-has-its-first-genuine-sure-fire-oscar-contender-and-maybe-a-palme-dor-winner-too-1202393905/|title=Cannes 2018 Has Its First Genuine Sure-Fire Oscar Contender, And Maybe A Palme d’Or Winner Too|publisher=Deadline|accessdate=May 31, 2018|archivedate=18 May 2018|df=}}</ref>
==History==
===French Mandate=== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:The-Adventures-of-Elias-Mabrouk.png|thumb|right|A still from ''The Adventures of Elias Mabrouk'' (1929)]] -->
Cinemas existed in Lebanon since the early 1920s, and a sharp increase in the number of theaters was observed between 1923-1929.<ref>Kassir, Samir. ''Beirut'', University of California Press; First edition (November 15, 2010), page 267</ref> By the end of the 1920s, cinemas were common in Beirut, and some were used as a place for political gatherings. For example, in 1925, the Communist Party met at the Crystal Cinema in Beirut.{{sfn|Thompson|2000|p=200}} Cinemas had become so popular that in 1931, students marched in a protest, demanding that prices of movie tickets be lowered.{{sfn|Thompson|2000|p=200}} To compete against Hollywood, France decreed that all American films that were being imported to Lebanon be dubbed into French.{{sfn|Thompson|2000|p=201}}
The first local film, ''The Adventures of Elias Mabruk'', was made in 1929.<ref name="Ginsberg 2010">Ginsberg, Terri and Chris Lippard. ''Historical Dictionary of Middle Eastern Cinema'', Scarecrow Press (March 11, 2010), page xxiii</ref> It was a silent film, directed by Jordano Pidutti.{{sfn|Shafik|2007|p=12}} Pidutti was an Italian immigrant who worked as a chauffeur for the [[Sursock family]] before devoting his life to film.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://homemagazinelebanon.com/2016-04-07-14-47-47/item/1000-lebanese-cinema-film-makers-history-worlwide |title=CANNES 1957: THE DEBUT OF LEBANESE CINEMA |publisher=Home Magazine |date= |accessdate=31 May 2018 |deadurl=no|df=dmy-all }}</ref> His first film, ''The Adventures of Elias Mabruk'' tells the story of a Lebanese emigrant who returns to Lebanon after a long absence in America in search of his family.<ref>Sadoul, George. ''The Cinema in the Arab Countries'', Interarab Centre of Cinema & Television; First Edition in English edition, 1966</ref> This tale of an emigrant's homecoming, captured nostalgic feelings in a country of emigrants and would become a recurrent theme in Lebanese cinema.<ref name="Seigneurie, Ken 2011, page 96">Seigneurie, Ken. ''Standing by the Ruins: Elegiac Humanism in Wartime and Postwar Lebanon'', Fordham University Press, 2011, page 96</ref> Jordano Pidutti's second film was ''The Adventures of Abu Abed''.<ref>Ames, Roy. ''Arab Filmmakers of the Middle East: A Dictionary'', Indian University Press, Bloomington, IN 2010, page 110</ref> The comedy is considered the first film made with Lebanese funding.<ref name="Ginsberg 2010"/> The financier was Rachid Ali Chaaban, who was also the star of the film.<ref name="Khatib, Lina 2008, page 22">Khatib, Lina. ''Lebanese Cinema: Imagining the Civil War and Beyond'', I. B. Tauris, London 2008, page 22</ref><ref>Kuhn, Annette and Guy Westwell. ''A Dictionary of Film Studies'', Oxford University Press, London 2012, page 245</ref>
Lebanese women, like [[Assia Dagher]] and [[Mary Queeny]], played pioneering roles in Egyptian cinema. In Lebanon, Herta Gargour, who managed the film studio, Luminar Films, is credited with establishing filmmaking in Lebanon after the silent era.<ref name="Hillauer, Rebecca 2006 page 132">Hillauer, Rebecca. ''Encyclopedia of Arab Women Filmmakers'', The American University in Cairo Press; 1 edition (February 2, 2006), page 132</ref> ''In the Ruins of Baalbeck'' (1936), which was produced by Luminar Films,<ref name="Hillauer, Rebecca 2006 page 132"/> was the first sound film.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0250250/ Bayn Hayakel Baalbek (1936) – IMDb<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> It was a hit with audiences and profitable.{{sfn|Thompson|2000|p=202}} The film, which was directed by Julio De Luca and Karam Boustany, depicted the love story of a local prince who falls in love with a foreigner.<ref name="Seigneurie, Ken 2011, page 96"/> The film is considered the first Arab film produced entirely in an Arab country and featuring the [[Lebanese Arabic|Lebanese dialect]].<ref>Ginsberg, Terri and Chris Lippard. H''istorical Dictionary of Middle Eastern Cinema'', Scarecrow Press (March 11, 2010), page xxiii</ref>
Ali Al-Ariss became the first Lebanese-born to direct a film on his own when he made ''The Rose Seller'' in 1940, which was followed by ''Planet of the Desert Princess''<ref name="Khatib, Lina 2008, page 22"/>
Documentaries were also being made during this period, but they were heavily censored by the French.{{sfn|Thompson|2000|p=201}}
===Post-Independence=== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:IlaAyn-George-Nasser.jpg|thumb|right|''Vers L'Inconnu'', A Film by Georges Nasser]] --> After Lebanon gained its independence from France, filmmakers began to examine local themes, especially rural life and folklore.<ref name="Armes, Roy page 7">Armes, Roy. ''Arab Filmmakers of the Middle East: a Dictionary'', page 7</ref> During the post-independence period, Lebanon witnessed an economic boom that made its capital, [[Beirut]], the financial center of the eastern Mediterranean.{{sfn|Westmoreland|2008|p=70}} Lebanon's economic success, along with the presence of 38 banks and its open, multi-cultural and liberal society, made the country an alternative production choice to Egypt, which was at the time the center of filmmaking in the Arabic-speaking world.{{sfn|Westmoreland|2008|p=71}} Additionally, "Lebanon had the region's best technical facilities" for film production.<ref>Chaudhuri, Shohini. ''Contemporary World Cinema: Europe, the Middle East, East Asia and South Asia'', page 60</ref> Fully equipped studios were set up in 1952, such as Haroun Studio owned by Michel Haroun and Al-Arz Studio<ref>Khatib, Lina. ''Lebanese Cinema: Imagining the Civil War and Beyond'', I. B. Tauris, London 2008, page 22-23</ref>
For the first half of the twentieth century, Lebanese cinema was very closely associated with Egyptian cinema.{{sfn|Shafik|2007|p=29}} In addition to exporting numerous Lebanese actors and actresses, such as Nour Al Hoda and [[Sabah (singer)|Sabah]], belly dancers like Badia Massabni and producers like [[Assia Dagher]], Lebanese distributors monopolized export of Egyptian film from 1930s – 1970s.{{sfn|Shafik|2007|p=28}}
The first Lebanese film to be featured In Selection at [[Cannes Film Festival]] was [[Georges Nasser (filmmaker)|Georges Nasser's]] ''Ila Ayn?'' in 1958.<ref name="Ham, Anthony page 411">Ham, Anthony. ''Middle East'', Lonely Planet 2012, page 411</ref> Despite its success abroad and having been screened at numerous film festivals, such as in Moscow and Beijing, the movie theaters in Lebanon hesitated to screen the film, and it only received a limited screening in Cinema Opera.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://homemagazinelebanon.com/2016-04-07-14-47-47/item/1000-lebanese-cinema-film-makers-history-worlwide |title=CANNES 1957: THE DEBUT OF LEBANESE CINEMA |publisher=Home Magazine |date= |accessdate=31 May 2018 |deadurl=no|df=dmy-all }}</ref> For its sixty-year anniversary, the film was screened again in its restored print version as part of the Cannes Classics events in 2017.<ref name="https">{{cite web|title="Georges Nasser, the grandfather of Lebanese cinema and director of ''Ila Ayn''?"|url=https://www.festival-cannes.com/en/69-editions/retrospective/2017/actualites/articles/georges-nasser-the-grandfather-of-lebanese-cinema-and-director-of-ila-ayn}}</ref> George Nasser's work has been more appreciated in recent years, and the filmmaker, who teaches at the [[Lebanese Academy of Fine Arts]] has been showered with accolades, including at the Tripoli Film Festival, which was held in his honor in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|title="Putting Tripoli on the International Screen "|url=https://en.annahar.com/article/582594-putting-tripoli-on-the-international-screen}}</ref>
Co-productions with Egypt and Syria were common in this period, which was considered the "Golden Age" of the Lebanese film industry.<ref name="Armes, Roy page 7"/> Additionally, Lebanese producers from 1945 up to 1951 played an influential role in the first stages of production of Iraqi cinema.{{sfn|Shafik|2007|pp=27–28}}
====The Golden Age====
The film industry continued to prosper in the 1960s. After [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] nationalized the film industry in Egypt in 1963, many private producers, distributors and directors, including [[Youssef Chahine]], moved to Lebanon.<ref name="Gugler, Josef 2015, page 103">Gugler, Josef. ''Ten Arab Filmmakers: Political Dissent and Social Critique'', Indiana University Press, Bloomington 2015, page 103</ref> The migration of film production to Beirut ushered a Golden Age, making Lebanon the film set for almost all Egyptian movies and establishing the Lebanese film industry as the second largest in the Arab world.<ref>{{cite web|title="Just Like the Movies: Lebanon's Film Industry"|url=http://irresistible.alrifai.com/2016/03/23/just-like-the-movies-lebanons-film-industry-2/}}</ref> Beirut rivaled Cairo’s dominance of Arab filmmaking, and even briefly replaced it as the center for Arab filmmaking;<ref>Kiarostami, Abbas. ''The Cinema of North Africa and the Middle East'', Wallflower Press, London 2007, page 160</ref> however, films produced in the sixties, for the most part, lacked a sense of national identity and were merely commercial films, targeting a pan-Arab audience.<ref name="Armes, Roy page 7"/> For instance, Lebanese filmmaker, Mohammed Selmane made a series of Bedouin-themed films, like ''Bedouin in Paris'' (1964) and ''Bedouin in Rome'' (1965), both starring [[Samira Tewfik]] and targeting not only local but also Syrian, Iraqi, Jordanian and Gulf audiences.<ref>Leamen, Oliver. Companion Encyclopedia of Middle Eastern and North African Film, Routledge London, 2001, page 375</ref> Mohamed Selmane, who was trained in Egypt and returned to Lebanon to make 30 films in 25 years, was one of the most successful directors of this period.<ref name="Armes, Roy page 7"/>
The musicals of the Rahbani Brothers that starred [[Fairuz]] were an exception to the films that lacked a national identity. The Rahbani films were centered around nostalgic themes of life in [[Mount Lebanon]] villages.<ref>Stone, Christopher Reed. ''Popular culture and nationalism in Lebanon: the Fairouz and Rahbani Nation'', pages 75–76</ref> Nostalgia was a common theme in Lebanese film since 1929.<ref name="Seigneurie, Ken 2011, page 96"/> While many films in the sixties were filmed in the Egyptian vernacular to cater to the large Egyptian market, the Rahbani films were filmed in the Lebanese dialect.{{sfn|Westmoreland|2008|pp=72–73}} ''The Seller of Rings'' (1965), set in a [[Maronite]] village and displaying folkloristic elements, was an adaption of one of their operettas to the screen.<ref name="Gugler, Josef 2015, page 103"/> Another Rahbani film, ''[[Safar Barlik]]'', which was set in 1912, depicted Lebanon's struggle against the Ottoman occupation. The film became a staple rerun on Lebanese television, especially on Independence Day.<ref>Frishkopf, Michael. Music and Media in the Arab World, page 98</ref>
There were other exceptions like the auteur films of George Nasser and Youssef Maalouf. Georges Nasser's second feature, ''The Small Stranger'' was also selected for Cannes in 1962.<ref name="https"/> Youssef Maalouf adapted to film [[Kahlil Gibran|Kahlil Gibran's]] novel, ''[[Broken Wings (Gibran novel)|The Broken Wings]]'' in 1962.<ref>Seigneurie, Ken. ''Standing by the Ruins: Elegiac Humanism in Wartime and Postwar Lebanon'', Fordham University Press, 2011, page 97</ref> Prints of the film ''[[The Broken Wings]]'' were believed to have been destroyed during the war, but one was found after the war stored in a church, and the film, starring stage actress Nidal Al-Askhar, was restored.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://filmthreat.com/uncategorized/the-broken-wings/ |title=The Broken Wings |publisher=Film Threat |date= |accessdate=4 June 2018 |archivedate=7 February 2003}}</ref>
Lebanon was also a filming location for international productions. For example, in 1965, [[Val Guest]]'s ''[[Where the Spies Are]]'', starring [[David Niven]] and [[Françoise Dorléac]], was filmed in Beirut.<ref name="Kassir, Debevoise page 407">Kassir, Debevoise, and Fisk. ''Beirut'', page 407</ref> ''Twenty-Four Hours to Kill'',<ref name="imdb.com">[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0059836/ Twenty-Four Hours to Kill (1965) – IMDb<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> starring [[Mickey Rooney]], and ''[[Secret Agent Fireball]]'', starring [[Richard Harrison (actor)|Richard Harrison]], were also filmed in Beirut the same year.<ref name="imdb.com"/> The following year in 1966, the German director, Manfred R. Köhler, filmed his film, ''[[Agent 505: Death Trap in Beirut]]''. [[George Lautner]]'s ''La grande sauterelle'' was also filmed in Beirut in 1967.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0061729/ La grande sauterelle (1967) – IMDb<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> ''[[Rebus (film)|Rebus]]'', starring [[Ann-Margret]] was filmed on location at the [[Casino du Liban]] in 1969. While ''[[Honeybaby, Honeybaby]]'' was shot in 1974 in Beirut, the producers of ''[[The Man with the Golden Gun (film)|The Man with the Golden Gun]]'', which was partially set in Beirut, decided not to film in the Lebanese capital due to the burgeoning political problems.<ref name="Kassir, Debevoise page 407"/>
In 1965, [[UNESCO]] established the Arab Cinema Liaison Center<ref>Ginsberg, Terri and Chris Lippard. H''istorical Dictionary of Middle Eastern Cinema'', Scarecrow Press (March 11, 2010), page xxvii</ref> at the National Cinema Center in Beirut as a regional hub for linking cinema activities across the Arab world.<ref name="Khatib, Lina 2008, page 22"/> Beirut hosted the first international film festival in the Arab world in 1971.<ref name="Armes, Roy page 7"/> Until the mid-1970s, the film industry in Lebanon was flourishing with market appeal that extended to neighboring Arabic-speaking countries.<ref name="Kuhn page 239">Kuhn, Anne and Radstone, Annette. ''The Women's Companion to International Film'', page 239</ref> Lebanon was producing "a string of sexually indulgent films" such as ''Cats of Hamra Street''<ref>Kassir, Debevoise, and Fisk. ''Beirut'', page 391</ref> and ''The Guitar of Love'' in 1973,{{sfn|Westmoreland|2008|p=73}} starring [[Georgina Rizk]], the Lebanese beauty queen who won Miss Universe in 1971.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.missuniverse.com/contestant_profiles/past |title=Contestant Profiles |publisher=Miss Universe |date= |accessdate=16 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130925075702/http://www.missuniverse.com/contestant_profiles/past |archivedate=25 September 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In the 1970s, cinema attendance in Lebanon was the highest among Arabic-speaking countries.<ref name="Armes, Roy page 204">Armes, Roy. ''Third World film making and the West'', page 204</ref>
[[Heiny Srour]] became not only the first Lebanese and Arab woman to have her film in competition at the [[1974 Cannes Film Festival]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.artistikrezo.com/agenda/l-heure-de-la-liberation-a-sonne-documentaire-de-heiny-srour.html|title=L’Heure de la liberation a sonné – documentaire de Heiny Srour |publisher=Artistik Rezo |date=16 June 2016}}</ref> but her documentary film ''The Hour of Liberation Has Arrived'' was actually the first film by any female filmmaker to be screened at the festival.<ref>Stone, Rob, with Paul Cooke, Stephanie Dennison, Alex Marlow-Mann. ''The Routledge Companion to World Cinema'', Routledge; 1 edition (October 3, 2017), page 209</ref>
===Civil War=== Prior to the civil war, 161 films, mostly commercial melodramas, were produced in Lebanon and exported to various Arab countries, but when the civil war began, film production decreased tremendously.<ref>Hillauer, Rebecca. ''Encyclopedia of Arab Women Filmmakers'', The American University in Cairo Press; 1 edition (February 2, 2006), page 131</ref>
Despite the war, there was an "emergence of a new wave of Lebanese filmmakers – fostering, unusually, equal numbers of women and men".<ref name="Kuhn page 239"/> The female filmmakers, who emerged during this period, made highly acclaimed and internationally renowned films.<ref name="Leamen, Oliver 2001, page 374">Leamen, Oliver. Companion Encyclopedia of Middle Eastern and North African Film, Routledge London, 2001, page 374</ref> Some of the filmmakers who emerged during this period were "[[Maroun Baghdadi]], [[Jocelyne Saab]], [[Borhane Alaouié]], [[Heiny Srour]], [[Randa Chahal Sabag]]" and Jean Chamoun.<ref>Westmoreland, Mark R. "Post-Orientalist Aesthetics: Experimental Film and Video in Lebanon"</ref> In the 1970s, film themes in Lebanon were concentrated around the political conflicts that the country was undergoing.<ref name="Armes, Roy page 204"/> Displacement was also a recurrent theme as evident in Borhane Alaouie's ''Beirut, the Encounter'' (1981).{{sfn|Westmoreland|2008|p=80}} Films of this period were characterized by a lack of closure, reflective of the seemingly endless war at the time.{{sfn|Westmoreland|2008|p=82}}
One of the most important directors to emerge during this period was Maroun Baghdadi. According to Lina Khatib, author of ''Lebanese Cinema: Imagining the Civil War and Beyond'', Baghdadi's films were "considered the cornerstone of Lebanese cinema".<ref>{{cite web|author=– Saturday |url=http://www.thenational.ae/arts-culture/books/the-view-from-lebanon?pageCount=2 |title=Page 2/3: The view from Lebanon |publisher=The National |date= |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref> Maroun Baghdadi made ''[[Little Wars (film)|Little Wars]]'' (1982) with aid provided by the American filmmaker, Francis Coppola.<ref>Kuhn, Anne and Radstone, Annette. ''The Women's Companion to International Film'', page 239-240</ref> The film was screened in the [[Un Certain Regard]] section at the [[1982 Cannes Film Festival]].<ref name="festival-cannes.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/1704/year/1982.html |title=Festival de Cannes: Little Wars |accessdate=12 June 2009|work=festival-cannes.com}}</ref> The film also screened at New York Film Festival on 2 October 1982.<ref name="NY Times">{{cite news |url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9F03EFD8123BF931A35753C1A964948260 |title=Movie Review: Little Wars |accessdate=15 October 2011|work=NY Times |first=Janet |last=Maslin |date=2 October 1982}}</ref>
Documentaries by filmmakers like Jocelyne Saab who "adopted a mainly journalistic style" also developed rapidly and successfully during this period.<ref name="Kuhn page 239"/> Lebanese and Palestinian documentaries produced in Lebanon during the 1970s caused a surge of documentary production across the Arab world.<ref name="Armes, Roy page 26"/> These documentaries contributed to the development of feature film production in the early eighties.<ref name="Armes, Roy page 26"/>
Many filmmakers from this era, such as Jocelyne Saab, Jean Chamoun, Randa Chahal Sabbag, and Maroun Baghdadi settled in France due to the prolonged conflict in Lebanon.<ref>Armes, Roy. ''Arab Filmmakers of the Middle East: a Dictionary'', page 27</ref>
''[[Beirut: The Last Home Movie]]'' is a 1987 documentary film that was directed by [[Jennifer Fox (documentary filmmaker)|Jennifer Fox]] and shot on location at the historic [[Bustros]] mansion in Beirut. The documentary, which told the story of one of Lebanon’s wealthiest families, was awarded the Excellence In Cinematography Award and won the Grand Jury Prize Documentary at the 1988 Sundance Film Festival.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://history.sundance.org/films/953 |title=Beirut: The Last Home Movie |publisher=Sundance Institute |date= |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref>
Despite the war, Lebanon submitted a film for the first time for consideration for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film when ''Promise of Love'' (1978) an Armenian-language film by Sarky Mouradian was submitted to the [[List of submissions to the 51st Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film|51st Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oscars.org/oscars/ceremonies/1979 |title=The 51ST Academy Awards, 1979 |publisher=The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences |date= |accessdate=29 May 2018}}</ref>
In addition to the wave of festival films and documentaries, a series of commercial films, mostly mimicking action [[B movie]]s from Hollywood, were made in the early 1980s.<ref>{{cite web|author=– Saturday |url=http://www.thenational.ae/arts-culture/books/the-view-from-lebanon |title=The view from Lebanon |publisher=The National |date= |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref> Prominent directors such as Youssef Charafeddine and Samir El-Ghoussaini aspired for escapism in their films to take their audiences out of the context of the war.<ref>Khatib, Lina. ''Lebanese Cinema: Imagining the Civil War and Beyond'', IB Tauris & Comapny, London 2008, page xiv,</ref> Films such as ''The Last Passage'' (1981), ''The Decision'' (1981), and ''The Leap of Death'' (1982) were popular because they depicted a society free of war where law and order actually existed.<ref name="Leamen, Oliver 2001, page 374"/> Other commercial films, like ''Ghazl Al-Banat'', incorporated the war in the narrative.<ref name="Leamen, Oliver 2001, page 374"/> The era of commercial film production ended with the [[1982 Lebanon War|Israeli war on Lebanon]].<ref name="Leamen, Oliver 2001, page 374"/>
===Post-War Revival=== After the war, Beirut reemerged as one of the centers of mass media production in the Arab world.{{sfn|Westmoreland|2008|p=91}} While media production was concentrated around television, there were attempts to revive the film industry in Lebanon, especially by fresh graduates of Lebanese film schools. While filmmaking schools are a rarity in the region, by the mid-1990s, six of Beirut's universities were offering degrees in cinema and television and that attracted an influx of students from Arab countries who chose to receive some or all of their media training in Lebanon.<ref name="ReferenceA">Marks, Laura U. "What Is That and between Arab Women and Video? The Case of Beirut"</ref> Financing of film production in Lebanon in this period was mainly dependent on foreign support, both European and from the Lebanese diaspora.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
The civil war was a major theme for Lebanese filmmakers since 1975, and this trend continued in the early post-war era where films continued to be affected thematically by the war.<ref>Khatib, Lina. ''Lebanese Cinema: Imagining the Civil War and Beyond'', IB Tauris & Comapny, London 2008, page xx</ref> Films made after the war had a common theme of returning to the war setting and dealing with trauma common to post-conflict societies.<ref name="Rastegar, Kamran 2015, page 155">Rastegar, Kamran. ''Surviving Images: Cinema, War, and Cultural Memory in the Middle East'', Oxford University Press, New York, 2015, page 155</ref>
Many films, such as Jocelyne Saab's experimental film, ''Once Upon a Time in Beirut'', examined the destruction that was left after the war.<ref>Ginsberg, Terri and Lippard, Chris. [https://rowman.com/ISBN/9780810860902 ''Historical Dictionary of Middle Eastern Cinema''], page 310</ref> Maroun Baghdadi's Beyrouth ''Hors la Vie'' won the Special Jury Prize at Canned in 1991.<ref>Hammond, Andrew. ''Pop Culture Arab World!: Media, Arts, and Lifestyle'', page 132</ref> Other's like Jean-Claude Codsi's ''Histoire d'un retoure'' examined the issue of returning to the country after years of exile and war.<ref name="ReferenceB">Westmoreland, Mark R."Post-Orientalist Aesthetics:Experimental Film and Video in Lebanon"</ref> In 1994, Codsi's film won the jury award at the ''Festival international du film Francophone'' de Namur in Belgium.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amanofhonor-thefilm.com/index.php/the-cast/89-cms/130 |title=Jean-Claude Codsi Biography |publisher=Amanofhonor-thefilm.com |date= |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref>
In 1997, Youssef Chahine's French-produced film, ''Destiny'', was shot on location in Lebanon, including the historic mountain town of in [[Beiteddine]].
While many films produced in the 1990s were hits at international festivals, Lebanese viewers were not drawn to the mainly war-themed films. An exception was ''[[West Beirut (film)]]'' (1998), which was a local and an international hit. It was not only the first Lebanese film, but also the first Arabic-language film to have general release in America.<ref>Hammond, Andrew. ''Pop Culture Arab World!: Media, Arts, and Lifestyle'', page 115</ref> The film, that received worldwide attention, was the first Lebanese film that the post-war generation in Lebanon actually saw in cinemas, and it ushered a new era in Lebanese filmmaking that historian, Lina Khatib calls a renaissance.<ref>Khatib, Lina. ''Lebanese Cinema: Imagining the Civil War and Beyond'', IB Tauris & Comapny, London 2008, page xiv</ref>
===Renaissance in the 21st century=== A mélange of local issues and Western aesthetics characterized this period of Lebanese filmmaking.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Films in this period gained domestic appeal where many films were not only commercially successful as evident in box-office sales of ''Bosta'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://yalibnan.com/site/archives/2006/01/bosta_-_a_100_l_1.php |title=Bosta – A 100% Lebanese Feature Film |publisher=Ya Libnan |date=22 January 2006 |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/middle-east-film-comes-age-150703 |title= Middle East film comes of age|publisher=''The Hollywood Reporter'' |date=21 September 2007 |accessdate=23 May 2018}}</ref> ''Caramel'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/Opinion/Editorial/2011/Sep-20/149189-embracing-art.ashx#axzz1avJ8EJl6 |title=Embracing art |publisher=The Daily Star |date=20 September 2011 |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref> ''Stray Bullet'', and ''Where Do We Go Now?''<ref>{{cite web|last=Wiseman |first=Andreas |url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/distribution/labakis-where-do-we-go-now-breaks-new-ground-in-lebanon/5032857.article |title=Labaki’s Where Do We Go Now? breaks new ground in Lebanon |publisher=Screendaily.com |date=4 October 2011 |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref> but also were able to compete with imported, American films. Funding of films remained reliant on European organizations, such as ''Fonds Sud Cinéma'' in France and ''Organisation Internationale de la Francophonie''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amanofhonor-thefilm.com/index.php/the-cast/89-cms/128 |title=Jean-Claude Codsi Interview |publisher=Amanofhonor-thefilm.com |date= |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref> Philippe Aractingi's ''[[Bosta (film)]]'' is one of the few films that was completely funded locally.
====2000s==== Ghassan Salhab's ''Terra Incognito'' (2002) screened in Un Certain Regard in Cannes.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.sudouest.fr/2010/07/06/ghassan-salhab-mon-pays-c-est-le-cinema-133318-4628.php | location=France | work=Soudouwest | first=Christine | last=Poulin | title=OGhassan Salhab : " Mon pays, c’est le cinéma " | date=7 June 2010}}</ref> In 2003, [[Randa Chahal]]'s ''[[The Kite (film)|The Kite]]'' examined the issue of families separated due to the occupied territories in southern Lebanon. Her film won the Silver Lion at the Venice Film Festival.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2008/oct/03/lebanon | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Olivia | last=Snaije | title=Obituary: Randa Chahal | date=3 October 2008}}</ref>
Also in 2003, Georges Schoucair returned to Lebanon after studying film in France and established Abbout Productions, the country's first post-war production house, which has become Lebanon's "foremost production house and one of the most prominent companies for art-house films in the region".<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.mei.edu/content/article/revival-lebanese-cinema| location=Washington DC | work=Middle East Institute | first=Joseph | last=Fahim | title=The Revival of Lebanese Cinema | date=21 December 2016}}</ref>
By 2004, film production was on the increase with four fiction and two documentaries produced.<ref>Deutsch, Andre. ''Variety International Film Guide''</ref> Joana Hadjithomas and Khalil Joreige’s ''The Perfect Day'' (2005) examined the social implications of political kidnappings that happened during the war.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Ghassan Salhab's ''[[The Last Man (2006 film)|The Last Man]]'' (2006) represented the cultural memory of the war from the eyes of a vampire protagonist caught in limbo between life and death.<ref name="Rastegar, Kamran 2015, page 155"/> ''Zozo'' (2005) by Josef Fares follows the life of a young boy and his journey to flee the war to Sweden.<ref>Rastegar, Kamran. ''Surviving Images: Cinema, War, and Cultural Memory in the Middle East'', Oxford University Press, New York, 2015, page 173</ref> New themes that did not necessary deal with the issue of war emerged, like Danielle Arbid’s ''In the Battlefields'' (2005) that critiqued patriarchal society. Filmmakers began to examine the postwar context rather than living in or surviving the war.<ref>Rastegar, Kamran. ''Surviving Images: Cinema, War, and Cultural Memory in the Middle East'', Oxford University Press, New York, 2015, page 164</ref> Michel Kammoun's ''Falafel'' (2005) about disillusioned youth in post-war Beirut premiered in 2006 at Cinema Days of Beirut, a festival which was not cancelled despite the Israeli bombardment of the capital as a sign of "cultural resistance".<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/5357342.stm | location=London | work=BBC | first=Saeed | last=Taji Farouky | title=eirut festival's defiant gesture | date=19 September 2006}}</ref> « ring of fire » Zenar el nar by Bahij Hojeij in 2004
Short film production, especially by the graduates of the film schools in Lebanon, was also on the increase and receiving local and international attention. Hany Tamba's ''[[After Shave (2005 film)|After Shave]]'' won the César Award for best short film in 2006.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/event/ev0000157/2006 César Awards, France (2006)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
2007 was an important year for Lebanese filmmaking when two female directors, [[Nadine Labaki]] and [[Danielle Arbid]] presented their films at the Cannes Film Festival. Labaki presented ''Caramel'' while Arbid presented ''A Lost Man''.<ref name="Ham, Anthony page 411"/> ''A Lost Man'' is possibly the most sexually graphic film ever made by an Arab director.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.variety.com/graphics/print_pdfs/0521cnd14.pdf |title=Arbid pushes limit with sexy ‘Man’ |publisher=Variety |format=PDF |date=21 May 2007 |accessdate=16 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090320033800/http://www.variety.com/graphics/print_pdfs/0521cnd14.pdf |archivedate=20 March 2009 }}</ref> ''Caramel'' enjoyed an international release, including in the United States, United Kingdom, France, and Argentina.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0825236/business Sukkar banat (2007) – Box office / business<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
====2010s==== According to research conducted by Fondation Liban Cinema, "The film industry in Lebanon has seen a significant growth over the last four years, with 31 movies produced in 2014, compared to just four a decade ago.".<ref name="fondationlibancinema.org">http://www.fondationlibancinema.org/pdf/Graphs%20presentation-FINAL.pdf</ref> Ghassan Salhab's ''The Mountain'', which was produced by Abbout Productions, had its international premiere during the Doha-Tribeca Film Festival.<ref name="Variety">{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2010/film/features/lebanese-helmer-works-on-his-own-terms-1118028002/|title="Lebanese helmer works on his own terms" |publisher=Variety |date=24 November 2010|accessdate=June 4, 2018}}</ref>
=====2010===== In 2010, 11 films were produced in Lebanon.<ref name="fondationlibancinema.org"/> Muriel Abourouss won the best director of photography award for Georges Hachem's ''[[Stray Bullet (2010 film)|Stray Bullet]]'' at the ''Festival international du film Francophone'' de Namur in Belgium.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fiff.be/fr/Archives/25-ans-25-FIFF/2010/Liste-des-films/Balle-perdue |title=Balle perdue / Liste des films |language=French |publisher=Fiff.be |date= |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref> Vatche Boulghourjian filmed on location in [[Bourj Hammoud]], ''[[The Fifth Column (film)|The Fifth Column]]'' a short film in Western Armenian dialect that won the third place Cinéfondation Prize at the Cannes Film Festival.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.festival-cannes.fr/en/theDailyArticle/57807.html |title=Cinéfondation Prizes 2010 |publisher=Festival-cannes.fr |date= |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref>
''Ok, Enough, Goodbye'' by [[Rania Attieh and Daniel Garcia]] was shot on location in Tripoli, Lebanon in 2010. The film tied with Delphine and Muriel Coulin's ''Ragazze'' for the Special Jury Award ex-aequo at the Torino Film Festival in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.torinofilmfest.org/?action=article&id=286 |title=29 Torino Film Festival – Awards |publisher=Torinofilmfest.org |date= |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref>
Also in 2010, ''Carlos'', a [[Canal+]] production that starred Édgar Ramírez as well as a handful of Lebanese stars such as Razane Jammal, Rodney El Haddad, Antoine Balabane, Ahmad Kaabour, Talal El-Jordi and Badih Abou Chakra was shot on location in Lebanon.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1321865/locations "Carlos" (2010) – Filming locations<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> ''Carlos'', which screened out of competition at the 2010 Cannes Film Festival won the 2010 Golden Globe award for the Best Miniseries or Motion Picture Made for Television.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.popsugar.com.au/Carlos-Wins-Best-Mini-Series-Motion-Picture-Made-Television-13289789 |title=Carlos Wins Best Mini-Series or Motion Picture Made For Television |publisher=Popsugar.com.au |date=17 January 2011 |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref>
=====2011===== Increase in film production was evident in 2011 with 24 movies produced.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fondationlibancinema.org/pdf/Graphs%20presentation-FINAL.pdf|title=Fondacio Liban Cinema Report on Film Industry|publisher=FLC |date=31 October 2015 |accessdate=31 May 2018}}</ref> Nadine Labaki's ''Where Do We Go Now?'' won the Prix Francois Chalais at Cannes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.femalefirst.co.uk/entertainment/Doha+Tribeca+Film+Festival-99727.html |title=Doha Tribeca Film Festival's (DTFF) Contemporary World Cinema Programme Revealed |publisher=Femalefirst.co.uk |date=28 September 2011 |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref> The film also won the people's choice award at the Toronto International Film Festival as well as the audience award at the [[Films from the South]] Festival in [[Oslo]], [[Norway]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Av Ingrid Stolpestad, foto: Ulf Hansen 17. okt 2011 |url=http://www.filmfrasor.no/en/news/2011/10/pricewinners.html |title=Award winners of Films From the South 2011 – Films from the South |publisher=Filmfrasor.no |date= |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref> Sony Pictures Classics acquired the American rights to the film.<ref name="reuters.com">{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/09/29/us-wheredowegonow-idUSTRE78S07320110929 | work=Reuters | title=Sony Classics picks up "Where Do We Go Now?" | date=29 September 2011}}</ref> The film was Lebanon's choice to compete in the Academy Award's "Best Foreign-Language Film" category.<ref name="reuters.com"/> The film also won the Byarad d'Or at the ''Festival international du film Francophone'' de Namur in Belgium<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fiff.be/fr/Actualites/Palmares-de-la-26e-edition |title=FIFF – Palmarès de la 26e édition / Actualités |publisher=Wayback.archive.org |date=18 October 2011 |accessdate=16 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120104064141/http://www.fiff.be/fr/Actualites/Palmares-de-la-26e-edition |archivedate=4 January 2012 }}</ref> and the Doha Tribeca Film Festival's Best Narrative Film award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tradearabia.com/news/MEDIA_207351.html |title=Star shows, premieres mark DTFF closing |publisher=Tradearabia.com |date=31 October 2011 |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref>
[[Circumstance (2011 film)|''Circumstance'']], a film by Maryam Keshavarz that explored homosexuality in modern Iran, was filmed entirely on location in Beirut.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1684628/ Circumstance (2011) – IMDb<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
In the summer of 2011, the city of Beirut participated in the [[48 Hour Film Project]] for the first time where 24 teams competed.<ref name="48hourfilm.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.48hourfilm.com/beirut/ |title=The 48 Hour Film Project: Beirut |publisher=48hourfilm.com |date= |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref> Cyril Aris won the Best Film category for his short, "Anoesis," which will be Beirut's entry in Filmapalooza 2012, the final festival for the 2011 48 Hour Film Project.<ref name="48hourfilm.com"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.48hourfilm.com/filmapalooza/ |title=The 48 Hour Film Project: Filmapalooza 2013 |publisher=48hourfilm.com |date= |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref><ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2061578/ Anoesis (2011) – IMDb<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Danielle Arbid's filmed her third feature, ''Beirut Hotel'',<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117945800/ | work=Variety | first=Jay | last=Weissberg | title=Beirut Hotel | date=11 August 2011}}</ref> which had a world premiere at the 64th Locarno Film Festival in August 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://varietyarabia.com/Docs.Viewer/19e3b3b6-e4d8-4990-8b11-4a37e0a4cd4c/default.aspx |title="Beirut Hotel" to premiere at Locarno film festival |publisher=Varietyarabia.com |date=7 August 2011 |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref>
Mounir Maasri's ''Rue Huvelin'', which was set in 1990, told the story of seven [[Saint Joseph University]] students from Beirut's [[Rue Huvelin]] during the Syrian occupation of Lebanon.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1837646/ Rue Huvelin (2011) – IMDb<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Né à Beyrouth produced the film.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/company/co0247997/ Né à Beyrouth [lb]<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Jean-Claude Codsi filmed his second feature, ''A Man of Honor'', which was produced by Michel Ghosn and premiered at the Doha Tribeca Film Festival on 28 October 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dohafilminstitute.com/filmfestival/films/a-man-of-honor |title=A Man of Honor |publisher=Doha Film Institute |date= |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref>
''Beirut Kamikaze'', an Experimental/Documentary by Christophe Karabache was released in cinema (Paris) on 16 November 2011.
Also in 2011, Celine Abiad's Beiroots Productions presented a different perspective of Mediterranean filmmaking by producing and experimental surrealist film (5.1 Dolby surround), shot in 35mm and fully produced in Lebanon: ''A Play Entitled Sehnsucht'', written and directed by Badran Roy Badran. The film was picked up for international distribution at Cannes, by Albany Films International, a company dedicated to the promotion of art house and indie films from gifted and promising directors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.albanyfilmsinternational.com/about.html |title=About Us |publisher=Albany Films International |date= |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.albanyfilmsinternational.com/aplay.html |title=A play entitled Sehnsucht |publisher=Albany Films International |date= |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref>
Documentary filmmaking was also present in 2011. Rania Stephan won "Best Documentary Filmmaker" at the Doha Tribeca Film Festival for ''The Three Disappearances of [[Soad Hosny]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dohafilminstitute.com/filmfestival/awards |title=Awards — Doha Tribeca Film Festival |publisher=Doha Film Institute |date= |accessdate=16 February 2013}}</ref> ''It's All in Lebanon'', a documentary film directed by Wissam Charaf and produced by Né à Beyrouth Production, premiered at DIFF in 2011. Hady Zaccak’s Marcedes screened at the Marché du Film. It received several awards, including Best Documentary at the International Federation of Film Critics at the Dubai International Film Festival and the Al-Jazeera Documentary Channel Award for Best Long Film at Al-Jazeera International Documentary Festival.<ref>{{cite web|title="'Marcedes' by Hadi Zaccak at the Marché du Film"|url=http://www.35mmnews.com/cannes/marcedes-by-hady-zaccak-at-the-marche-du-film-on-may-23/}}</ref>
Thirteen feature and short films were premiered at DIFF in 2011, including Danielle Arbid's ''Beirut Hotel'', Youcef Joe Bou Eid's ''Tannoura Maxi'', Daniel Joseph's ''Taxi Ballad'', Simon El Habre's ''Gate #5'', Hady Zaccak's ''Marcedes'', Rami Nihawi's ''Yamo'', Christina Foerch Saab's ''Che Guevara Died in Lebanon'', Tamara Stepanyan's ''19 February'', Wajdi Elian's ''A Place to Go'', Rodrigue Sleiman and Tarek El Bacha's ''Nice to Meet You'', Aseel Mansour's ''Uncle Nashaat'', and Nadim Mishlawi's ''Sector Zero''.<ref>[http://www.dubaifilmfest.com/index.php/en/diff-2011/2011-films/#pg-1_g-none_l-none_co-Lebanon_ci-none_se-none_sec-none] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111207224321/http://www.dubaifilmfest.com/index.php/en/diff-2011/2011-films/#pg-1_g-none_l-none_co-Lebanon_ci-none_se-none_sec-none|date=7 December 2011}}</ref>
=====2012===== Steady increase in film production continued with 25 films produced in 2012.<ref name="fondationlibancinema.org"/> Lara Saba completed her second feature, ''Blind Intersections''.<ref>{{cite web|title="Blind Intersections"|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/reviews/blind-intersections-1117948948/}}</ref> Despite being critically acclaimed, Ziad Doueiry's film, [[The Attack (2012 film)|''The Attack'']] was banned in Lebanon because it was filmed on location in Israel.<ref>{{cite web|title="The Effort to Stop ‘The Attack’"|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/16/magazine/the-effort-to-stop-the-attack.html}}</ref> ''74, La reconstitution d'une lutte'', a docu-fiction by Raed and Rania Rafei, recreates the student occupation of the American University in Beirut 1974.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/5/32/128062/Arts--Culture/Film/Film--When-Lebanons-past-and-present-are-different.aspx |title=Al-Ahram |publisher="Film '74': When Lebanon's past and present are different yet the same" |date=19 April 2015 |accessdate=4 June 2018}}</ref>
=====2013===== The number of films produced in 2013 were 24.<ref name="fondationlibancinema.org"/> [[Amin Dora|Amin Dora's]] [[Ghadi (film)|''Ghadi'']], which was released in late 2013, became Lebanon's entry to the [[List of submissions to the 87th Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film|Oscars's Foreign Language category]]<ref>{{cite web|title="Oscars: Lebanon Selects 'Void' for Foreign-Language Category"|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/oscars-lebanon-selects-foreign-language-825654}}</ref> and later won the KNN Award (Audience Award) at the [[Busan International Film Festival]].<ref>http://www.biff.kr/eng/html/archive/arc_history19_01.asp</ref> [[Philippe Aractingi]] completed and released his documentary feature film, ''Heritages''.<ref name="hollywoodreporter.com">{{cite web |title= ‘Listen’ (‘Ismaii’): Film Review {{!}} Dubai 2016 |url= https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/listen-review-960771}}</ref>
=====2014===== The number of films produced in Lebanon jumped to 31 films in 2014, and this also reflected an increase in the number of production companies, including 27 focusing only on films.<ref name="fondationlibancinema.org"/> One of the most prominent films of the year was ''Void'', written by George Khabbaz and directed by seven different directors, all of them graduates of Notre Dame University, and the film would be selected as Lebanon's entry to compete at the Oscars in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title="Oscars Foreign-Language Race: The Complete List, 2015"|url=https://www.thewrap.com/oscars-foreign-language-race-the-complete-list-so-far/}}</ref> Ghassan Salhab reunited with actors Carlos Chahine and Carole Abboud in ''The Valley'', which premiered at the Toronto International Film Festival.<ref>{{cite web|title="'The Valley' ('Al-Wadi'): Toronto Review, 2015"|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/valley-al-wadi-toronto-review-734530}}</ref> ''The Valley'' was shot on 35 mm.<ref name="Variety"/>
=====2015===== There were 31 produced films in 2015, growing 675% since 2004.<ref>{{Cite web|title ="NETFLIX, CANNES, AND THE INCREDIBLE GROWTH OF LEBANESE CINEMA"|url = http://www.beyondartisculture.com/netflix-cannes-and-the-incredible-growth-of-lebanese-cinema/}}</ref>
In 2015, Noura Kevorkian's drama-documentary hybrid feature film ''23 Kilometres'' was selected for documentary competition at Karlovy Vary International Film Festival<ref>{{Cite web|title = KVIFF {{!}} Film detail|url = http://www.kviff.com/en/programme/film/3316101-23-kilometres/|website = www.kviff.com|accessdate = 25 November 2015}}</ref> as well as Muhr Feature Award competition at Dubai International Film Festival.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Dubai International Film Festival - Films 2015 - 23 KILOMETRES|url = http://dubaifilmfest.com/en/films/41397/23_kilometres.html|website = Dubai International Film Festival|accessdate = 25 November 2015}}</ref>
=====2016===== Two government initiative were passed in 2016 that benefited the film industry. The first was the memorandum of understanding (MOU) signed by the Fondation Liban Cinema and the Investment Development Authority of Lebanon (IDAL) which added the media industry, including film production, to IDAL’s mandate of bringing investment to the country and offering incentives such as 100 percent tax exemption on corporate profits for up to 10 years.<ref name="No stone unturned">{{cite web|title="No stone unturned"|url=http://www.executive-magazine.com/special-report/filmfinancing}}</ref> The other initiative was Banque du Liban's offering of $100 million in loan guarantees at the low interest rate of 1 percent.<ref name="No stone unturned"/> [[Banque du Liban]] also issued Intermediate Circular 416, which subsidizes loans of up to $3 million by banks and financial institutions to support film, television and theatrical productions<ref name="The Future is FIlm">{{cite web|title="The Future is FIlm"|url=http://www.executive-magazine.com/culture/the-future-is-film}}</ref>
In 2016, ''Solitaire'', Sophie Boutros's first feature film, premiered at the 13th Dubai International Film Festival<ref>https://variety.com/2016/film/festivals/arabian-nights-and-laylm-m-provide-feminist-slant-to-dubai-film-fest-1201929421/</ref> and [[Philippe Aractingi]]'s feature film, ''Listen'' was also screened at Dubai Film Festival's Arabian Nights.<ref name="hollywoodreporter.com"/>
''A Maid for Each'', a documentary by Maher Abi Samra about domestic servants in Lebanon, won the Peace Film Prize at Berlin Film Festival and Post-Production Awards at Final Cut in Venice 2014.<ref name="IDAL-Sectors in Focus">{{cite web|title="IDAL-Sectors in Focus"|url=http://investinlebanon.gov.lb/en/sectors_in_focus/media/lebanese_movies}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title="'A Maid for Each' Review"|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/reviews/a-maid-for-each-film-review-1201952631/}}</ref>
One of the biggest hits of 2016 was the film, ''What About Tomorrow?'' a restoration of old 8mm footage of Ziad Rahbani’s 1978 play.<ref name="No stone unturned"/> The film chattered box office records in Lebanon.<ref>{{cite web|title="Lebanese Film ‘What About Tomorrow?’ Crushes Box Office Records In The Country"|url=http://deadline.com/2016/01/lebanese-film-ziad-rahbani-what-about-tomorrow-crushes-box-office-records-in-lebanon-fairuz-civil-war-1201688154/}}</ref>
=====2017===== In December 2017, [[Lucien Bourjeily]]'s debut feature film ''[[Heaven Without People]]'' won the Special Jury Prize award at the [[Dubai International Film Festival]] while [[Vatche Boulghourjian]]'s [[Tramontane (film)|''Tramontane'']] was selected for Cannes’ Critics’ Week.<ref>{{cite web |title= Tramontane review – musical road trip untangles trauma of Lebanese civil war |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2017/sep/22/tramontane-review-vatche-boulghourjian}}</ref>
After being supported by the Venice Biennale College - Cinema Program, ''Martyr'' (2017) by Mazen Khaled premiered at the [[Venice Film Festival]] on September 2, 2017 where it won the Queer Lion Award.<ref name="queerty.com">{{cite web|title="New film "Martyr" explores where masculinity, homoeroticism, and Islam intersect"|url=https://www.queerty.com/watch-new-film-martyr-explores-masculinity-homoeroticism-islam-intersect-20180314}}</ref><ref name="IDAL-Sectors in Focus"/> The gay-themed film also screened at the [[South by Southwest|SXSW Film Festival]], where it was included in the festival’s official LGBTQ film selections.<ref name="queerty.com"/> Breaking Glass Pictures acquired the film for American theatrical distribution.<ref>{{cite web|title="Breaking Glass Pictures acquires Lebanese drama 'Martyr"|url=https://www.screendaily.com/news/breaking-glass-pictures-acquires-lebanese-drama-martyr-exclusive/5128758.article}}</ref>
The documentary, ''Taste of Cement'' (2017) by Syrian filmmaker Ziad Kalthoum was filmed in Lebanon with Lebanese director of photography Talal Khoury and received a [[Cinema Eye Honors]] nomination<ref>{{cite web|title="'Taste of Cement': Film Review"|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/taste-cement-review-1082273}}</ref> and won the International Competition at Visions du Réel.<ref>{{cite web|title="'Taste Of Cement' wins top prize at Visions du Réel in Nyon"|url=https://www.screendaily.com/news/taste-of-cement-wins-top-prize-at-visions-du-reel-in-nyon/5117299.article}}</ref>
Rana Eid's documentary, ''Panoptic'', which will be released in cinemas in 2018, premiered at the 2017 Locarno Film Festival and received a First Lights from the Jihlava Film Festival in the Czech Republic.<ref>{{cite web|title="Dubai: Arab World Women Directors: Rana Eid, ‘Panoptic’"|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/festivals/dubai-arab-world-women-directors-rana-eid-panoptic-1202633755/}}</ref>
Among the 13 participating Arab countries, Lebanon had the most nominations at the Arab Film Institute's first edition of the Arab Film Awards.<ref name="screendaily.com">{{cite web|title="Nominations revealed for inaugural Arab Film Awards"|url=https://www.screendaily.com/news/nominations-revealed-for-inaugural-arab-film-awards/5124732.article}}</ref> The films were: ''The Traveller'' by Hadi Ghandour, Jihane Chouaib's ''Go Home'', ''Listen'' by Philippe Aractangi, ''Single, Married Divorced'', a comedy by Shady Hanna, the romantic comedy ''Solitaire'' by Sophie Boutros, Roy Dib's ''The Beach House'', and ''Tramontane'' by Vatché Boulghouroujian.<ref name="screendaily.com"/>
=====2018===== With [[List of Academy Award winners and nominees for Best Foreign Language Film|Oscar]] and [[2018 Cannes Film Festival|Palme D'or]] nominations, 2018 marked a pivotal point for Lebanese cinema on the international stage.
In March, [[Ziad Doueiry]]'s [[The Insult (film)|''The Insult'']] was nominated for an Academy Award for [[List of submissions to the 90th Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Language Film]], the first for Lebanon.<ref>{{cite web|title="‘The Insult’ Director Ziad Doueiri Overcame Political Controversy To Take Oscar Nod For Best Foreign Language Film"|url=http://deadline.com/2018/02/the-insult-ziad-doueiri-oscars-foreign-language-panel-news-1202283622}}</ref>
[[Nadine Labaki|Nadine Labaki's]] [[Capernaum (film)|''Capernaum'']], which was selected to compete for the [[Palme d'Or]], earned a 15-minute standing ovation following its premiere on May 17, 2018 at the [[2018 Cannes Film Festival|Cannes Film Festival]].<ref>{{cite web|title="Nadine Labaki’s ‘Capernaum’ Earns Massive Cannes Standing Ovation and Instant Palme d’Or Winner Predictions"|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2018/05/nadine-labaki-capernaum-cannes-standing-ovation-palme-dor-1201965910/}}</ref> The film won the Jury Prize.<ref>{{cite web|title="Cannes Film Festival 2018: Winners and Losers Inside the Perfect Storm"|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2018/05/cannes-changing-film-industry-winners-sinners-1201963623//}}</ref>
Tony Farjallah's ''Morine'', a film about a 7th-century woman who disguises herself as a man in order to live in a monastery, is considered the first historical film set in Lebanon.<ref>{{cite web|title="Morine, a Spiritual Journey into History"|url=http://www.lau.edu.lb/news-events/news/archive/morine_a_spiritual_journey_int/}}</ref> Other films made were Michel Kammoun's ''Beirut Hold’em'', Nadim Tabet’s ''One of These Days'', Rana Eid's documentary ''Panoptic'' and Joanna and Khalil Joreige’s ''The Notebooks'' a co-production of Abbout Productions and France’s Haut et Court.<ref name="The Future is FIlm"/><ref>{{cite web|title="Joana Hadjithomas and Khalil Joreige (‘The Lebanese Rocket Society’) set to Shoot ‘The Notebooks’"|url=https://variety.com/2018/film/festivals/joana-hadjithomas-and-khalil-joreige-the-lebanese-rocket-society-set-to-shoot-the-notebooks-1202703352/}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox cinema market | name = Cinema of Mongolia | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | screens = 24 (2011)<ref name=screens_uis>{{cite web|title=Table 8: Cinema Infrastructure - Capacity|url=http://stats.uis.unesco.org/unesco/TableViewer/tableView.aspx?ReportId=5542|publisher=UNESCO Institute for Statistics|accessdate=5 November 2013}}</ref> | screens_per_capita = <!-- per 100,000 <ref name=screens_uis/> --> | distributors = {{br separated entries|Tengis cinema|Urguu cinema|Soyombo cinema}}<ref name=distributors_uis>{{cite web|title=Table 6: Share of Top 3 distributors (Excel)|url=http://stats.uis.unesco.org/unesco/ReportFolders/reportFolders.aspx|publisher=UNESCO Institute for Statistics|accessdate=5 November 2013}}</ref> | produced_year = 2011 | produced_ref = <ref name=production_uis>{{cite web|title=Table 1: Feature Film Production - Genre/Method of Shooting|url=http://stats.uis.unesco.org/unesco/TableViewer/tableView.aspx?ReportId=5545|publisher=UNESCO Institute for Statistics|accessdate=5 November 2013}}</ref> | produced_total = | produced_fictional = 1 (7.7%) | produced_animated = - | produced_documentary = 12 (92.3%) | admissions_year = 2011 | admissions_ref = <ref name=adm_gross_uis>{{cite web|title=Table 11: Exhibition - Admissions & Gross Box Office (GBO)|url=http://stats.uis.unesco.org/unesco/TableViewer/tableView.aspx?ReportId=5538|publisher=UNESCO Institute for Statistics|accessdate=5 November 2013}}</ref> | admissions_total = 1,916,700 | admissions_national = | box_office_year = | box_office_ref = <ref name=adm_gross_uis/> | box_office_total = [[Mongolian tögrög|MNT]] {{Format price|5108614700}} | box_office_national = <!-- ${{Format price| }} --> }} The '''cinema of Mongolia''' has been strongly influenced by the [[cinema of Russia]], which differentiates it from cinematic developments in the rest of Asia.
== History == It is assumed that the first cinematographic performances in [[Mongolia]] happened between 1903 and 1913, as private events for the prince [[Tögs-Ochiryn Namnansüren]] and the [[Jebtsundamba]] in the capital [[Ulan Bator|Urga]].
After the socialist revolution, the [[Mongolian People's Party|Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party]] decided in its fifth congress of 1925 to use movies as an instrument of mass education. From 1926 on, mobile projection facilities would regularly show [[USSR|Soviet]] films to the Mongolian people. The first permanent cinema "Ard" ({{lang|mn|ард}}, ''people'') opened in the capital (now named [[Ulaanbaatar]]) in 1934. Eventually, every [[Aimags of Mongolia|aimag]] center would have fixed cinemas, and every [[sums of Mongolia]] or [[negdel]] would have a mobile cinema. In the 1990s, many cinemas, fixed and mobile alike, closed down or reduced activities.
=== Mongol Kino === The national film studios, ''Mongol Kino'', were founded in 1935, with Soviet technical assistance. Their first productions were a documentary on the "47th anniversary of the 1st May" and a fictional story named A Mongol son (''Mongol Khüü'') directed by the Russian [[Ilya Trauberg]] and Mongolian Demberel Baldan. The first Mongolian-directed movie was the black-and-white short feature Norjmaa's Destiny (''Norjmaagiin Zam'') by Baldan in 1938.
From then on, the Mongolian movie production focused around heroic revolutionary propaganda and ancient popular legends, still often under Russian direction. This program was very successful with movies like Sükhbaatar (1942) and Tsogt Taij (1945). The studios of Mongol Kino also produced documentaries and current news reports.
=== 1950s and 1960s === After World War II, the party moved the focus on working-class heroes, reflected in movies like New Year (''Shine Jil'', 1954) by Tseveeny Zandraa. Examples of this genre are Awakening (''Serelt'', 1957) by S. Genden and [[The Rejected Girl]] (''Gologdson khüükhen'') by Dendevyn Chimid-Osor. In 1955, the first musical comedy appeared, which started a trend that continued into the 1960s. The first color movie was The Golden Yurt (''Altan Örgöö'', 1961), based on a folktale. It was produced in cooperation with the [[German Democratic Republic|East German]] [[DEFA]] studios. The music of the film, written by L. Mördorj, was played and recorded by the GDR Radio orchestra and became a classic of the Mongolian [[symphony]]. As a fairy tale film, it is rich with [[match moving]] and other [[special effects]] of [[cinematography]].
=== 1970s and 1980s === While the production of documentaries increased, the fictional stories turned to everyday life in the 1970s. One of the most famous movies of that time, ''The Crystal Clear Tamir River'' (''Tungalag Tamir'', 1970) by Ravjagiin Dorjpalam, based on the novel by [[Chadraabalyn Lodoidamba]], is however set during Mongolia's 1921 revolution. Other well-known productions were "The Legend of the Mother Oasis" ("Ehe Bürdiin domog"), made in 1976 by Gombojav Jigjidsuren (Гомбожавын Жигжидсүрэн) and Jamyangiin Buntar (Жамъяангийн Бунтар), and The Five Colors of the Rainbow (''Solongiin tavan öngö'') in 1979. The Leading Wrestler [[Garuda]] (''Garid Magnai'', 1983) by [[Jamyangiin Buntar]] marks a turning point, where the authors liberate themselves from the existing power structures.
=== 1990s and 2000s === After the introduction of the market economy, most mobile and permanent cinemas closed down. Mongolian productions had to seek partners outside of the former [[Comecon|COMECON]]. However, some young filmmakers of the transformation period, such as N. Gankhuyag, B. Uranchimeg, J. Binder, made domestic success films.
The movie "Genghis Khan, Under Power of the Eternal Sky", starring [[Enkhtaivan Agvaantseren]] was the first Mongolian-Japanese co-production. [[State of Dogs]] (''Nokhoin Oron'', 1998) was written and directed collaboratively by the Belgian Peter Brosens and the Mongolian Dorjkhandyn Turmunkh.
The director [[Byambasuren Davaa]] has had international success with the German-Mongolian co-productions [[The Story of the Weeping Camel]] (2003, nominated for an [[Academy Award]] as a foreign documentary in 2005) and [[The Cave of the Yellow Dog]] (2005).
Elsnii Nuudel ({{lang-mn|Элсний нүүдэл}}, ''movement of sand''), was a successful movie produced for the domestic market in 2007. Later known films are Iim negen durlal, Goyoliin Daashinz, etc.
The 2008 historical film [[A Pearl in the Forest]] ({{lang-mn|Мойлхон}}) by director [[Enkhtaivan Agvaantseren]] is one of the first films to openly talk about events of the 1930s and the impact of the rise of [[Soviet communism]] on Mongolia. It is also one of the first films intended to present the history of the [[Buryats]], one of the ethnic groups present in Mongolia.
