{{Infobox comics creator | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_place = [[High Point, North Carolina]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = American | cartoonist = | write = y | art = | pencil = y | ink = y | edit = | publish = | letter = | color = y | alias = | signature = | notable works = ''[[Silverheels]]''
''[[Simon Dark]]'' | awards = | website = http://www.mothcomix.com/html/Artists/Hampton-Scott.asp | subcat = American | birth_date={{Birth date and age|1959|4|10}} }} '''Scott Hampton''' (born April 10, 1959) is an [[People of the United States|American]] [[comic book artist]] known for his painted artwork. He is the brother of fellow-comics-creator [[Bo Hampton]]. ==Early life== Scott Hampton was born in 1959 in [[High Point, North Carolina]].{{fact|date=October 2015}} ==Career== Hampton began his career following in the footsteps of brother and fellow comic book creator [[Bo Hampton]]. Both Scott and Bo studied under [[Will Eisner]] in 1976. Scott's first professional comics work was the three-page story "Victims" published in [[Warren Publishing]]'s ''[[Vampirella]]'' #101 in 1981. Scott's work on ''[[Silverheels]]'' from [[Pacific Comics]] in 1983 is regarded as the first continuing painted comic (of U.S. origin). Working as a freelance [[Comic book creator|comic book artist]], Hampton has illustrated such iconic properties as [[Batman]], [[Sandman (Vertigo)|Sandman]], [[Black Widow (Natalia Romanova)|Black Widow]], [[Hellraiser]], and [[Star Trek]] in addition to work on his creator-owned projects such as ''The Upturned Stone''. His works include ''[[Spookhouse]]'', released in 2004 by [[IDW Publishing]], in which he adapted his favorite ghost stories into sequential form, and ''[[Batman: Gotham County Line]]'' from [[DC Comics]] in 2005. Hampton is currently working full-time on the creator-owned series ''[[Simon Dark]]'' with writer [[Steve Niles]] for DC Comics. Hampton has illustrated cards for the ''[[Magic: The Gathering]]'' collectible card game. "The Upturned Stone" was optioned mid-2005 for film production by [[David Foster Productions]], but the studio lost the option and the story was recently optioned by another producer. Scott is also pursuing a passion outside of comics: film making. He completed his first short independent film "The Tontine" in April 2006. It's his loose adaptation of a 21-page comic piece that he worked on and appeared by the same name in the ''[[Hellraiser (comics)|Hellraiser]]'' comic series. The 29 minute film was shot at the same cabin used in Eli Roth's "[[Cabin Fever (2002 film)|Cabin Fever]]". The complete short can be found on [[IMDB]] as well as versions of it available to view on [[Myspace]] (partial), [[Google Video]] (full), and [[YouTube]] (split into 3 parts). ==Personal life== Hampton lives with his wife Letitia in [[Chapel Hill, North Carolina]].{{fact|date=October 2015}} ==Bibliography== {{Expand section|date=June 2010}} Interior comics work includes: *''[[Silverheels]]'' (with writers [[April Campbell]]/[[Bruce Jones (comics)|Bruce Jones]], 4-issue mini-series but only 3 were published, [[Pacific Comics]], December 1983 - May 1984) *''[[Batman: Night Cries]]'' (script and art, with co-author [[Archie Goodwin (comics)|Archie Goodwin]], 96 page [[graphic novel]], [[DC Comics]], hardcover, 1992, {{ISBN|1-56389-059-3}}, softcover, 1993, {{ISBN|1-56389-066-6}})[http://www.dccomics.com/graphic_novels/?gn=1257 ''Batman: Night Cries''] at DC Comics.com *''[[Gen13]]: Bootleg'' #7 ([[Image Comics]], 1997) *''[[Sandman Presents]]: [[Lucifer (DC Comics)|Lucifer]]'' (with [[Mike Carey (writer)|Mike Carey]], 3-issue mini-series, [[Vertigo (DC Comics)|Vertigo]], March–May 1999) *''[[Batman: Gotham County Line]]'' #1-3 (with [[Steve Niles]], 3-issue mini-series, DC Comics, 2005) *''[[Simon Dark]]'' #1-18 (with Steve Nile, ongoing series, DC Comics, December 2007 - May 2009) *''Solo'' #9 (DC Comics, 2004) *''[[Shadowpact]]'' #13 (DC Comics, 2006) *''JSA 80-Page Giant'' (DC Comics, 2010) *''Black Widow: Breakdown'' #1-3 (with [[Greg Rucka]], Marvel Comics, 2001) *''Sky Horizon: Colony High; Bk 1'' (with [[David Brin]], Subterranean Press, 2007) ==Awards== *1993: Won "Special Award for Excellence in Presentation" [[Harvey Award]], for ''Batman: Night Cries''[http://www.harveyawards.org/awards_1993nom.html 1993 Harvey Award Nominees] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111002075943/http://harveyawards.org/awards_1993nom.html |date=2011-10-02 }}, the Harvey Awards ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== *{{gcdb|type=credit|search=Scott+Hampton|title=Scott Hampton}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.mothcomix.com/html/Artists/Hampton-Scott.asp}} * {{IMDb name|1898205}} *{{comicbookdb|type=creator|id=1549|title=Scott Hampton}} * [https://www.imdb.com/video/wab/vi2274755097/ The Tontine on IMDB] * {{LCAuth|nb98041856|Scott Hampton|17|}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hampton, Scott}} [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:American comics artists]] [[Category:Game artists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from High Point, North Carolina]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox company | name = Six Flags Entertainment Corporation | logo = Six Flags logo.svg | logo_size = | type = [[Public company|Public]] | traded_as = {{Unbulleted list|{{New York Stock Exchange|SIX}}|[[S&P 400]] component}} | industry = [[Amusement park]] operator | foundation = {{start date and age|1961|8|5}} | location = [[Grand Prairie, Texas|Grand Prairie]], [[Texas]], U.S. | num_locations = 25 | area_served = United States, Mexico, Canada | key_people = [[Jim Reid-Anderson]]
{{small|(Chairman, president, & CEO)}} | products = | revenue = {{increase}} US$1.359 billion (2017){{cite web|url=http://phx.corporate-ir.net/External.File?item=UGFyZW50SUQ9ODcwMDN8Q2hpbGRJRD0tMXxUeXBlPTM=&t=1|title=Annual Report|publisher=Six Flags|accessdate=April 16, 2015}} | operating_income = {{increase}} US$329.05 million (2017){{cite web|url=http://investors.sixflags.com/~/media/Files/S/SixFlags-IR/documents/annual-reports/2017-annual-report.pdf|publisher=Six Flags|accessdate=August 3, 2018|title=Income for Six flags}} | net_income = {{increase}} US$273.81 million (2017) | num_employees = 1,900 full-time; 27,000 seasonal | parent = | subsid = | website = {{URL|sixflags.com}} | footnotes = | Adjusted EBIDTA = }} '''Six Flags''', officially '''Six Flags Entertainment Corporation''', is an amusement park corporation based in the United States, with properties in the US, Canada, and Mexico. It is the largest amusement park company in the world, based on the number of properties owned, and is [[List of amusement park attendance figures|ranked seventh]] in terms of attendance.{{cite web|url=http://investors.sixflags.com/news-and-events/press-releases/2018/02-20-2018-120044735|title=Eighth Consecutive Record Year for Six Flags|date=February 20, 2018|website=|publisher=Six Flags Entertainment Corporation|accessdate=June 9, 2018}} The company maintains twenty five properties throughout North America including theme parks, amusement parks, [[water park]]s, and family entertainment centers. In 2017, Six Flags properties hosted 30.4 million guests. Six Flags was founded in Texas on August 5, 1961 and derived its name from its first property, [[Six Flags Over Texas]]. The company maintains a corporate office in [[Midtown Manhattan]], while its headquarters are in [[Grand Prairie, Texas]]. On June 13, 2009, the corporation filed for Chapter 11 [[bankruptcy protection]], which it successfully exited after restructuring on May 3, 2010.{{cite web|title=Six Flags Chapter 11 Petition|url=https://www.pacermonitor.com/view/XOCKPDY/Six_Flags_Great_Adventure_LLC__debke-09-12052__0001.0.pdf|website=PacerMonitor|publisher=PacerMonitor|accessdate=31 May 2016}}{{cite web | url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20090613005015/en/Flags-Enters-Final-Phase-Financial-Restructuring | title=''Six Flags Enters Final Phase of Financial Restructuring'' | publisher=businesswire.com|date=June 13, 2009 | accessdate=2011-04-15 }}{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/05/03/us-sixflags-idUSTRE6422RF20100503|title=Six Flags emerges from bankruptcy|author=Tom Hals|agency=Reuters|date=May 3, 2010|accessdate=2011-04-15}} ==History== === Origin === [[File:SixFlagsTrain-4027.jpg|thumb|right|Original [[Six Flags & Texas Railroad|Six Flags train]] still in operation (2007)]] The name "Six Flags" originally referred to the [[Six flags over Texas|flags of the six different nations that have governed Texas]]: Spain, France, Mexico, the [[Republic of Texas]], the United States, and the [[Confederate States of America]].{{cite book|author=Victoria W. Wolcott|title=Race, Riots, and Roller Coasters: The Struggle Over Segregated Recreation in America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AJbiA_sBjzYC&pg=PA158|date=16 August 2012|publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press|isbn=978-0-8122-0759-0|page=158}} Six Flags parks are still divided into different themed sections, though many of the original areas from the first three parks have been replaced. Six Flags Theme Parks originated in 1957 with the creation of ''The Great Southwest Corporation'' by [[Angus G. Wynne]] and other investors. Construction of "Six Flags Over Texas" started in 1960, and the park opened the next year for a short (45-day) season. The park initially featured a Native American village, a [[Gondola lift|gondola]] ride, a railroad, some [[Wild West]] shows, a [[stagecoach]] ride, and "Skull Island", a pirate-themed adventure attraction. There was also an excursion, inspired by the historical [[La Salle Expeditions]] in the late 1600s, called "LaSalle's River Adventure", aboard French riverboats through a wilderness full of animated puppets.{{cite web |url = http://www.csus.edu/indiv/s/shawg/articles/facilities/six_flags_timeline.html |title = Six Flags Timeline The Lands of Screams and Dreams |last = Shaw |first = Gregory B. C. |website = [[California State University, Sacramento]] |publisher = Self |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6MEbX9N5x?url=http://www.csus.edu/indiv/s/shawg/articles/facilities/six_flags_timeline.html |archivedate = December 29, 2013 |accessdate = 29 December 2013 |deadurl = yes |df = mdy }}, California.[http://parktimes.com/content/node/17 "La Salle's River Adventure 1961 – 1982"], ''ParkTimes.com'', August 15, 2010 Over time, all of those attractions, except for the railroad, would be replaced by others, such as [[roller coaster]]s, swing rides, [[log flume]]s, and shoot-the-chute rides, as well as an observation tower. === Growth and acquisitions === The original Six Flags park, [[Six Flags Over Texas]] in [[Arlington, Texas|Arlington]] (between [[Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex|Dallas and Fort Worth]]) was sold in 1966 to a subsidiary of the [[Pennsylvania Railroad]], which was actively pursuing non-railroad investments in an effort to diversify its sources of income. (In 1968, the Pennsylvania Railroad merged with the [[New York Central Railroad]] to form [[Penn Central]] Corp.) With the new owners came a more abundant supply of capital for geographic expansion and park additions. Six Flags opened [[Six Flags Over Georgia]] in 1967 and [[Six Flags St. Louis|Six Flags Over Mid-America]] in 1971, which would be the last two original parks constructed by the company. Six Flags continued to grow by acquiring independent parks. Six Flags purchased [[AstroWorld]] in [[Houston, Texas]] in 1975, [[Six Flags Great Adventure|Great Adventure]] in [[Jackson, New Jersey]] in 1977 and [[Six Flags Magic Mountain|Magic Mountain]] in [[Valencia, California]] in 1979. These purchases were followed by Penn Central selling assets to [[Bally Manufacturing]] in 1982. In 1984, the [[Six Flags Great America|Great America]] theme park in [[Gurnee, Illinois]] was acquired from the [[Marriott Corp.|Marriott]] hotel chain. Also in 1984, as a result of its acquisition of Great America, Six Flags acquired the rights to Time Warner/[[Warner Bros.]]' ''[[Looney Tunes]]'' animated characters for use in Six Flags properties. Bally surrendered control of the chain to [[Wesray Capital Corporation]] in a 1987 leveraged buyout. [[WarnerMedia|Time Warner]] quickly began to gain more leverage in the company, gaining a 19.5% stake in Six Flags in 1990 and then 50% in 1991, with the remaining shares of the company being split by [[Blackstone Group]] and Wertheim Schroder & Company. Time Warner purchased the remaining stake in Six Flags in 1993, changing the company's name from ''Six Flags Corp''. to ''Six Flags Theme Parks, Inc''. In 1996, Six Flags began to manage [[Six Flags Fiesta Texas|Fiesta Texas]] theme park in [[San Antonio|San Antonio, Texas]] and purchased the park from [[USAA]] in 1998. ===History of Premier Parks=== Premier Parks originally operated as the Tierco Group, Inc., an Oklahoma-based [[real estate]] company. The company purchased the [[Frontier City]] theme park in Oklahoma City in 1982 for $1.2 million, although Tierco had no intention of entering the amusement park business. Company officials described Frontier City as "beat up" and "run down"; they planned to demolish it, subdivide the land, and build a shopping center. However, given an [[1980s oil glut|oil bust]] in Oklahoma, developers lost interest in converting the park into a shopping center. In 1984 Tierco hired Gary Story as general manager of Frontier City and sunk about $13 million into improving the park. As the new head of Frontier City, he quadrupled the park's attendance and revenues. Under his leadership, two rides, a ticket booth, sales office, and a petting zoo were added to the park. Food service improved. In 1988, Tierco shifted its strategic direction to amusement parks. It sold much of its property in the late 1980s, generating capital to reinvest in Frontier City. As this reinvestment paid off, more capital became available, creating further growth. By 1991, Tierco opened White Water waterpark in [[Oklahoma City]] (the name later became [[White Water Bay (Oklahoma)|White Water Bay]]). The company realized the key to boosting a park's attendance was to add new and exciting rides, and make it [[Family-friendliness|family-friendly]]. Tierco acquired the financially troubled [[Six Flags America|Wild World]] in [[Largo, Maryland]], in 1992 and later changed that park's name to Adventure World. With a $500,000 investment, Tierco expanded Wild World's kiddie section and remodeled its buildings to give the park a [[Tropics|tropical]] look and feel. Story was promoted to [[vice president|executive vice president]] after the purchase of Wild World. In 1994, he was promoted again to president and [[chief operating officer|chief operating officer (COO)]]. More flat rides and two roller coasters were added to that park. Since Tierco was on its way to becoming a "premier" regional theme park operator, in 1994 it changed its name to Premier Parks, Inc. Kieran E. Burke, chairman and chief executive officer (CEO), noted that the new name signified the beginning of a new era for the company. In the second half of the 1990s, Premier picked up speed. In 1995, the company acquired these [[Funtime, Inc.]] properties: [[Geauga Lake (amusement park)|Geauga Lake]] near [[Cleveland|Cleveland, Ohio]], [[Zoombezi Bay|Wyandot Lake]] in [[Powell, Ohio]], [[Darien Lake]] near [[Buffalo, New York]], and [[Lake Compounce]] in [[Bristol, Connecticut]]. In 1996, Premier added to its portfolio, buying Elitch Gardens in [[Denver|Denver, Colorado]], the [[Waterworld California|Waterworld USA]] waterparks in [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]] and [[Concord, California]], [[Six Flags New England|Riverside Park]] in [[Agawam, Massachusetts]], and [[Great Escape and Splashwater Kingdom]] in [[Lake George (town), New York|Lake George, New York]]. Premier immediately sold the Lake Compounce park to [[Kennywood]] in Pennsylvania. Geauga Lake, Wyandot Lake, and Adventure World included water parks, while Frontier City was 14.8 miles away from White Water Bay that required separate admission. Riverside added one just before being sold. Premier Parks, in 1995 and 1996, added water parks to Darien Lake, Lake Compounce (immediately before the Kennywood sale), Elitch Gardens, and Great Escape. Premier went public in 1996 and raised nearly $70 million through an initial offering at $18 per share. The company planned to use the money to expand its ten parks and acquire others. In 1997, Premier purchased [[Kentucky Kingdom]] in [[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville]], and [[Six Flags Discovery Kingdom|Marine World]] near San Francisco. A second public offering, at $29 per share, raised an additional $2 million. Nearly 8.8 million people visited Premier's parks in 1996. Premier added amusement park rides and roller coasters to Marine World in 1998. ===Acquisition of Six Flags by Premier Parks=== Six Flags Theme Parks, Inc. was purchased in whole on April 1, 1998 from Time Warner by Premier Parks for $1.86 billion.{{cite news|title=Time Warner Completes Sale of Stake in Six Flags for $440 Million in Cash {{!}} Time Warner Inc.|url=http://www.timewarner.com/newsroom/press-releases/1998/04/01/time-warner-completes-sale-of-stake-in-six-flags-for-440-million|work=Time Warner|language=en}} Premier began to apply the Six Flags name to several smaller parks that the company had already owned: Darien Lake, [[Elitch Gardens Theme Park|Elitch Gardens]], [[Kentucky Kingdom]], and Adventure World. In 1999, Premier Parks purchased [[Warner Bros. Movie World Germany]] and the yet-to-be-built [[Warner Bros. Movie World Madrid]] from [[Warner Bros.]]. As part of the acquisition Premier Parks had the opportunity to open more European theme parks with Warner Bros. Movie World branding. [[Warner Bros. Movie World]] on the [[Gold Coast, Australia]] was not part of the deal. The same transaction saw Premier Parks obtain exclusive rights for Warner Bros. licensing in Europe and Latin America, in addition to their existing rights for the United States and Canada.{{cite journal|last=O'Brien|first=Tim|title=Premier Purchases WB's European Parks Division|journal=Amusement Business|date=October 18, 1999|volume=111|issue=42|pages=1, 32}} In 2000, Premier Parks assumed the ''Six Flags Theme Parks, Inc''. name and continued re-branding its parks, including the [[Geauga Lake (amusement park)|Geauga Lake]] park into Six Flags Ohio and Riverside Park to Six Flags New England. Six Flags began a vigorous expansion, attempting to branch out internationally, acquiring numerous properties across the USA, plus the [[Walibi]] chain, and the historic Belgian park [[Bellewaerde]] in Europe, [[La Ronde (amusement park)|La Ronde]] in [[Montreal, Quebec]], Canada, and [[Reino Aventura]] in Mexico. Three of those parks were re-branded as Six Flags parks: Walibi Flevo became [[Six Flags Holland]], Walibi Wavre became [[Six Flags Belgium]], and Reino Aventura became [[Six Flags Mexico]]. In 2001, Six Flags acquired the former [[SeaWorld#SeaWorld Ohio sale, re-birth, and eventual transition|SeaWorld Ohio]] from [[Busch Entertainment Corporation#History|Anheuser-Busch]], merged it with the adjacent Six Flags Ohio and re-branded the combined park as ''[[Six Flags Worlds of Adventure]]''.{{cite news|last1=Inc.|first1=Six Flags,|title=Six Flags, Inc. Purchases SeaWorld in Ohio|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/six-flags-inc-purchases-seaworld-in-ohio-71007317.html|work=www.prnewswire.com|language=en}} The park was positioned to compete against northern Ohio's [[Cedar Point]]. ===Asset sales and shareholder revolt=== [[File:Katrina Killed the Clown.jpg|thumb|On August 29, 2005, [[Six Flags New Orleans]] was severely damaged by [[Hurricane Katrina]]]] In 2004, Six Flags began to close and sell properties in an effort to help alleviate the company's growing debt. On March 10, Six Flags sold its European parks, with the exception of the Movie World park in [[Madrid]], Spain, to Star Parks, a division of Palamon Capital Partners.{{cite web|url=http://www.palamon.com/investment-portfolio/detail/starparks|title=investment Detail StarParks|publisher=Palamon Capital Partners, LP|accessdate=August 10, 2017}} The Madrid park was sold back to Time Warner and renamed "[[Parque Warner Madrid]]".{{cite news|last1=Meza|first1=Ed|title=Six Flags sells parks in Europe|url=https://variety.com/2004/biz/news/six-flags-sells-parks-in-europe-1117901725/|work=Variety|date=15 March 2004}} In April, Six Flags determined that the investment required to keep Worlds of Adventure competitive with Cedar Point would be too great, leading to that park being sold to [[Cedar Fair]].{{cite news|last1=L.P.|first1=Cedar Fair,|title=Cedar Fair, L.P. to Acquire Six Flags Worlds of Adventure|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/cedar-fair-lp-to-acquire-six-flags-worlds-of-adventure-72027297.html|work=www.prnewswire.com|language=en}} These sales raised $345 million in an effort to relieve Six Flags' massive debt.{{cite web|url=http://www.coastergallery.com/SFSale.html |title=Six Flags sells numerous parks |publisher=CoasterGallery.com |date=March 10, 2004 |accessdate=January 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719064605/http://www.coastergallery.com/SFSale.html |archivedate=July 19, 2011 |df= }} In 2005, Six Flags endured even more turmoil. Some of the company's largest investors, notably [[Bill Gates]]'s [[Cascade Investments]] (which then owned about 11% of Six Flags) and [[Daniel Snyder]]'s Red Zone, LLC (which owned 12%), demanded change. On August 17, 2005, Red Zone began a [[Proxy fight|proxy battle]] to gain control of Six Flags' board of directors. On August 29, [[Six Flags New Orleans]] was severely damaged by [[Hurricane Katrina]]. On September 12, Six Flags Chief Executive Officer Kieran Burke announced that [[Six Flags AstroWorld]] would be closed and demolished at the end of the 2005 season. The company cited issues such as the park's performance, and parking issues involving the [[Houston Texans]] football team, [[Reliant Stadium]], and the [[Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo]], leveraged with the estimated value of the property which included the park. Company executives were expecting to receive upwards of $150 million for the real estate, but ended up receiving $77 million when the bare property (which cost $20 million to clear) was sold to a development corporation in 2006.{{cite news|author=Houston Business Journal – by Jennifer Dawson |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/houston/stories/2006/05/08/daily27.html?from_rss=1 |title=Local developer to acquire former AstroWorld site – Houston Business Journal |publisher=Bizjournals.com |date= May 11, 2006|accessdate=January 2, 2011}} On November 22, Red Zone announced it had gained control of the board. Kieran Burke was removed on December 14 and replaced by [[Mark Shapiro (media executive)|Mark Shapiro]], former executive vice president of programming at [[ESPN]]. Six Flags then named former [[United States House of Representatives|Representative]] [[Jack Kemp]], entertainment mogul [[Harvey Weinstein]], and [[Michael Kassan]], the former president of the [[Interpublic Group of Companies Incorporated]], to their newly revamped board of directors. Even with the new management team, the sell-off would continue into 2006. On January 27, Six Flags announced the sale of Frontier City and White Water Bay after the 2006 operating season. At the same time, Six Flags announced it would close corporate offices in Oklahoma City, moving its headquarters to New York City. Six Flags CEO Mark Shapiro said he expected the parks to continue operation after the sale, a lesson the company learned after its public relations debacle with the closure of AstroWorld. In June, Six Flags announced it was considering closing or selling up to six of its parks, including Elitch Gardens, Darien Lake, WaterWorld in ([[Concord, California]]), [[Wild Waves Theme Park|Wild Waves and Enchanted Village]] in [[Federal Way, Washington]], [[Six Flags Splashtown|Splashtown]] in [[Houston, Texas]] and, most notably, [[Six Flags Magic Mountain]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thedenverchannel.com/money/9415831/detail.html?rss=den&psp=money |title=Six Flags Considers Selling Elitch Gardens – Money News Story – KMGH Denver |work=[[KMGH-TV]]|publisher=[[E.W. Scripps Company]] |date=June 23, 2006 |accessdate=January 2, 2011}} In addition, Six Flags announced the sale of Wyandot Lake in Powell, Ohio to the neighboring [[Columbus Zoo and Aquarium]].[http://www.dispatch.com/news-story.php?story=dispatch/2006/06/13/20060613-A1-01.html Zoo to keep Wyandot Lake afloat] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523050532/http://www.dispatch.com/live/contentbe/dispatch/2006/06/13/20060613-A1-01.html |date=May 23, 2011 }}'', Marla Matzer Rose. ''[[Columbus Dispatch]]'', June 13, 2006. Ultimately, Six Flags Magic Mountain was spared, with the remaining six parks sold on January 11, 2007 to [[CNL Lifestyle Properties]] for $312 million: $275 million cash and a note for $37 million.{{cite news|title=Six Flags owner to sell 7 parks for $312M|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/stlouis/stories/2007/01/08/daily34.html?page=all|accessdate=February 19, 2012|newspaper=St. Louis Business Journal|date=January 11, 2007}} === Bankruptcy === The company's cash flow had decreased by over $120 million annually during the Shapiro years. In October 2008, Six Flags was warned its stock value had fallen below the required minimums to remain listed on the [[New York Stock Exchange]].{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/03/12/AR2009031203317.html|title=For Six Flags, Debt Squeeze Looms as Latest Hurdle|author=Alejandro Lazo|work=The Washington Post|publisher=The Washington Post Company|date=March 13, 2009|accessdate=April 12, 2009}} With the [[financial crisis of 2007–2008]] weighing both on consumer spending and the ability to access credit facilities, Six Flags was believed to be unable to make a payment to preferred stockholders due in August 2009.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/14/business/14flags.html|title=Six Flags in Negotiations to Stave Off Chapter 11|author=Tim Arango|work=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Company|date=March 13, 2009|accessdate=April 12, 2009}} Management saw the business as a sound one, noting that attendance across the company's parks increased slightly in 2008 compared to 2007. Six Flags CEO Mark Shapiro said that the company's problem was the declining attendance and cash flow created by his new management initiatives. If not resolved, the company warned in its 2008 annual report{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/chi-tc-biz-brf-six-flags-0314mar14,0,1079808.story|title=Six Flags faces bankruptcy|work=Chicago Tribune|publisher=Tribune Publishing|date=March 14, 2009|accessdate=April 12, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090317200221/http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/chi-tc-biz-brf-six-flags-0314mar14,0,1079808.story|archive-date=March 17, 2009|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} that the situation might require a [[Chapter 11]] bankruptcy filing, with Six Flags already retaining counsel should that occur. The company stated at the time that it expected business to continue as normal in the event of such a filing, although one analyst believed attendance at the company's parks would decrease by six percent, suggesting parents would be leery of letting their children ride a roller coaster operated by a bankrupt company. In April 2009, the New York Stock Exchange announced it would [[Delisting (stock)|delist]] Six Flags' stock on April 20, a decision that the company did not intend to appeal.{{cite news|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/stories/2009/04/06/daily82.html|title=Six Flags delisted|publisher=Atlanta Business Journal|date=April 9, 2009|accessdate=April 12, 2009}} On June 1, 2009, Six Flags announced they would delay their $15 million debt payment further using a 30-day grace period. Less than two weeks later, on June 13, the firm filed for Chapter 11 [[Chapter 11, Title 11, United States Code|bankruptcy protection]],[[The Economist]]. June 20–26 weekly U.S. Edition. Page 8. but issued a statement that the parks would continue to operate normally while the company restructured.{{cite web|url=http://www.sixflags.com/national/footernav/frequentlyaskedquestions.aspx |title=Official Home Page |publisher=Six Flags |date= |accessdate=2014-06-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100419171245/http://www.sixflags.com/national/footerNav/frequentlyaskedquestions.aspx |archivedate=April 19, 2010 |df=mdy }} On August 21, 2009, Six Flags' Chapter 11 restructuring plan was announced in which lenders would control 92% of the company in exchange for cancelling $1.13 billion in debt.{{cite web|last=Church |first=Steven |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601103&sid=aPiLLmSHA91M |title=Six Flags Would Be Owned by Lenders Under Proposal (Update2) |publisher=Bloomberg |date=August 21, 2009 |accessdate=January 2, 2011}} One component of the restructuring was negotiating a new lease agreement with the [[Kentucky State Fair Board]], which owned much of the land and attractions for [[Kentucky Kingdom|Six Flags Kentucky Kingdom]].{{cite news|url=http://www.whas11.com/home/Kentucky-Kingdom-Park-to-Close-83593392.html |title=Six Flags theme park Kentucky Kingdom is closing |author=Janet Cappiello Blake |work=[[WHAS-TV]] |publisher=[[Tegna Inc.]] |date=February 5, 2010 |accessdate=February 8, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100207012047/http://www.whas11.com/home/Kentucky-Kingdom-Park-to-Close-83593392.html |archivedate=February 7, 2010 |df=mdy }} Six Flags had asked to forgo rent payments for the remaining nine years of its current lease agreement in exchange for profit-sharing from the park's operations.{{cite news|url=http://www.whas11.com/news/local/Whats-next-for-Six-Flags-Fair-Pres-says-rides-might-not-be-going-anywhere-83772172.html |title=What's next for Six Flags? No signs of reversal in closing decision |work=WHAS-TV |publisher=Tegna Inc. |date=February 7, 2010 |accessdate=February 8, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100210082641/http://www.whas11.com/news/local/Whats-next-for-Six-Flags-Fair-Pres-says-rides-might-not-be-going-anywhere-83772172.html |archivedate=February 10, 2010 |df=mdy }} When it appeared that the offer had been rejected, Six Flags announced in February 2010 that it would not re-open the park. However, the Kentucky State Fair Board stated at the time that they were still open to negotiating a revised lease agreement.{{cite news|url=http://www.whas11.com/community/blogs/political-blog/Fair-Board-Prescaught-by-surprise-with-6-Flags-closing-83608457.html |title=Fair Board Pres:"caught by surprise" with 6 Flags closing |author=Joe Arnold |work=WHAS11.com |date=February 4, 2010 |accessdate=February 8, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100207034757/http://www.whas11.com/community/blogs/political-blog/Fair-Board-Prescaught-by-surprise-with-6-Flags-closing-83608457.html |archivedate=February 7, 2010 |df=mdy }} On April 28, 2010, the company's bondholders reached an agreement on a reorganization plan.{{cite news|url=http://www.ajc.com/business/bondholders-agree-on-six-501251.html?cxntlid=daylf_artr|title=Bondholders agree on Six Flags reorganization|author=Randall Chase|work=Atlanta Journal-Constitution|publisher=Cox Enterprises|date=April 28, 2010|accessdate=May 5, 2010}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Junior note holders, including [[hedge fund]]s Stark Investments and Pentwater Capital Management, assumed control of the company, while senior note holders were paid in cash. Despite objections from some parties who stood to gain nothing, the bankruptcy judge approved the plan on April 30, 2010.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegram.com/article/20100502/NEWS/5020635/1002/BUSINESS|title=Chairman off Six Flags board|agency=Associated Press|work=Worcester Telegram|date=May 2, 2010|accessdate=May 5, 2010}} As part of the settlement, chairman of the board Dan Snyder was removed, while chief executive officer Mark Shapiro briefly remained in his post. === Emergence from bankruptcy === Six Flags officially emerged from bankruptcy protection as Six Flags Entertainment Corp. on May 3, 2010, and announced plans to issue new stock on the New York Stock Exchange. Amid suspected disagreements regarding the future of the company with the board, Shapiro left the company and Al Weber, Jr. was brought in as interim president and CEO.[https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN1219047320100512 Six Flags abruptly names interim CEO; Shapiro out], Reuters, May 12, 2010. The company announced their corporate headquarters would move from New York City to [[Grand Prairie, Texas]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/dn/latestnews/stories/070310dnbussixflags.fe89d4b1.html |title=Six Flags moving executives from New York to Grand Prairie | News for Dallas, Texas |publisher=Dallasnews.com |date=July 2, 2010 |accessdate=January 2, 2011}} === 2010–present === Six Flags announced that [[Jim Reid-Anderson]] would replace Weber and become [[chairman]], [[President (corporate title)|president]] and [[chief executive officer]] (CEO) on August 13, 2010.{{cite web |title=James Reid-Anderson Named Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer of Six Flags Entertainment Corporation |url=https://money.cnn.com/news/newsfeeds/articles/prnewswire/NY50230.htm |website=money.cnn.com |accessdate=25 November 2018}} John Duffey also joined the company in 2010, taking the role of [[chief financial officer]] (CFO). As of October 1, 2012, Al Weber, Jr. had retired as [[chief operating officer]] (COO) with no immediate successor. On February 18, 2016, Six Flags announced that [[Jim Reid-Anderson]] had been promoted as executive chairman and John M. Duffey succeeded him as president and CEO.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/dallas/news/2016/02/18/six-flags-jim-reid-anderson-to-split-duties-with.html|title=Six Flags' Jim Reid-Anderson to split duties with new CEO|last=Kezar|first=Korri|date=February 18, 2016|work=[[Dallas Bus. J.|Dallas Business Journal]]|access-date=}} On January 11, 2016, Six Flags announced [[Six Flags Zhejiang]], then named Six Flags Haiyan, in China. On the same day, a website was created along with concept art for the property.{{Cite web | url = https://content.sixflags.com/haiyan/?_ga=1.198714603.556601389.1452341845 | title = Six Flags Haiyan {{!}} | website = content.sixflags.com | access-date = 2016-02-27 }} A month later on February 2, 2016. Six Flags announced Six Flags Hurricane Harbor Oaxtepec.{{Cite web | url = https://content.sixflags.com/hurricaneharbormx/ | title = Hurricane Harbor Oaxtepec {{!}} | website = content.sixflags.com | access-date = 2016-02-27 }} The water park, originally named Parque Acuatico Oaxtepec, is a 76-acre park located in [[Morelos]] that went bankrupt in 2011.{{Cite web | url = http://www.sdpnoticias.com/local/morelos/2016/02/03/six-flags-anuncia-apertura-de-parque-acuatico-en-oaxtepec | title = Six Flags anuncia apertura de parque acuático en Oaxtepec | website = SDPnoticias.com | language = es-ES | access-date = 2016-02-27 | date = 2016-02-03 }} On March 21, 2016, Six Flags announced a partnership with NaVi Entertainment to build a Six Flags-branded theme park and a Six Flags Hurricane Harbor-branded water park in Vietnam.{{cite web|url=http://bizbeatblog.dallasnews.com/2016/03/six-flags-announces-new-park-for-vietnam.html/|title=Vietnam joins China, Dubai as international sites for Grand Prairie-based Six Flags parks|date=March 21, 2016|work=[[The Dallas Morning News]]|publisher=[[A.H. Belo|A.H. Belo Corporation]]}} On March 29, 2016, Six Flags announced the revival of its previously cancelled [[Six Flags Dubailand|Six Flags Dubai]]. As part of the second phase of the Dubai Parks and Resorts project in [[Jebel Ali]], the park is expected to open in 2019.{{cite web|url=http://www.screamscape.com/html/dubai_parks_-_resorts.htm|title=Six Flags Dubai planned to open in 2019|publisher=Screamscape|accessdate=March 29, 2016}} On July 20, 2016, Six Flags announced an agreement with Riverside Investment Group Co. Ltd. for the development of a second Six Flags-branded theme park in China together with a water park. The two parks will be located in [[Bishan District]], a district of [[Chongqing]].{{cite web|url=http://investors.sixflags.com/news-and-events/press-releases/2016/07-20-2016-141916453|title=Additional Six Flags-Branded Parks Coming to China|publisher=Six Flags|accessdate=July 20, 2016}} On April 27, 2017, the company announced it would take over operations of [[Waterworld California]] in [[Concord, California]] making it Six Flags' 20th property. On July 18, 2017, Six Flags announced that president and CEO John M. Duffey had retired from the company and Jim Reid-Anderson had re-assumed the roles of chairman, president, and CEO.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/dallas/news/2017/07/18/six-flags-ceo-steps-down-after-a-year-on-the-job.html|title=Six Flags CEO steps down after a year on the job|last=Kezar|first=Korri|date=July 18, 2017|work=[[Dallas Bus. J.|Dallas Business Journal]]|access-date=July 19, 2017|quote=The company did not explain Duffey’s departure, saying only that he has “retired from the company.”}}{{Cite press release|title=Reid-Anderson Named Chairman, President and CEO at Six Flags|date=July 18, 2017|publisher=Six Flags|location=Grand Prairie, Texas|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20170718005829/en/|via=BusinessWire} On March 22, 2018, Six Flags and Riverside Group announced a partnership with [[Turner Broadcasting System|Turner Asia Pacific]] to bring [[Tuzki]] and other Turner-owned IPs to its theme parks in China.{{cite web|url=http://investors.sixflags.com/news-and-events/press-releases/2018/03-22-2018-110034822|title=Six Flags and Riverside Partner with Turner to Offer New Attractions|website=investors.sixflags.com}} On May 22, 2018, Six Flags announced the purchase of operating leases for five parks owned by EPR Properties. The parks are [[Darien Lake]], [[Frontier City]], [[Wet'n'Wild Phoenix]], [[Wet'n'Wild SplashTown]], and [[White Water Bay (Oklahoma)|White Water Bay]].{{Cite web|url=http://investors.sixflags.com/news-and-events/press-releases/2018/05-22-2018-210951050|title=Six Flags Adds Five More Parks to US Portfolio|website=investors.sixflags.com|language=en|access-date=2018-05-23}} On October 9, 2018, Six Flags and [[Rockford Park District]] announced a lease agreement allowing Six Flags to operate [[Magic Waters|Magic Waters Waterpark]] beginning Spring 2019.{{Cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/lake-county-news-sun/news/ct-lns-six-flags-magic-waters-rockford-st-1010-story,amp.html|title=Six Flags strikes deal to operate Magic Waters in Rockford|website=chicagotribune.com|language=en|access-date=2018-10-10}} On October 24, 2018, Six Flags announced that the future of its [[Six Flags Dubai]] theme park was "uncertain" following losses at the company and its partner DXB Entertainments.{{cite web|title=Six Flags' Future in Dubai Is Now Uncertain|url=https://skift.com/2018/10/24/six-flags-future-in-dubai-is-now-uncertain/|website=Skift|language=en|date=2018-10-25}} ==Marketing efforts== ===TV commercials=== In 2004, although [[DC Comics]] and ''[[Looney Tunes]]'' as well as ''[[Scooby-Doo]]'' still had a major presence at the parks, Six Flags began a new series of [[Television commercial|commercials]] for the parks. The commercials introduced a new mascot: "[[Mr. Six (mascot)|Mr. Six]]", a seemingly feeble old man in a tuxedo and red bow tie. In many of the commercials, Mr. Six would slowly exit a multi-colored bus, only to start frenetically dancing to the [[Vengaboys]]' "[[We Like to Party (Vengaboys song)|We Like to Party]]". The commercials were an immediate hit and Mr. Six almost instantly became the de facto mascot, and his presence was felt for years after the character was retired. These ads have become widely parodied on the Internet, with faces from other Internet memes being superimposed over Mr. Six's face. From 2008 to 2010, Six Flags' TV ads consisted of a "Fun-O-Meter" in which the beginning of the ad showed something boring or embarrassing and a man's face judges it "One Flag!" or sometimes " Oh! Two Flags!" Then roller coasters and attractions of Six Flags are shown and says "Six Flags! More Flags, More Fun!" for Six Flags parks. However, the thick accent of the Asian man in the original commercials had drawn criticism for being an offensive caricature.{{cite news|url=http://www.amny.com/business/am-sixflags0805,0,3827486.story |title='Six Flags' TV ads get thumbs down from some Asian Americans |publisher=[[AM New York]] |last=Stride |first=Megan |date=August 5, 2008 |accessdate=August 5, 2008 }}{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In 2009, the Mr. Six character came back from retirement and replaced the Asian man in Six Flags' ads, still using the Fun-O-Meter. In 2011, Six Flags' TV ads got a brand-new slogan "Go Big! Go Six Flags!" for its theme parks. === Licensing with other brands and companies === Six Flags has licensed its name and its theme park creations to other companies, who have used these assets to create licensed products. One notable such example is the theme park simulation game [[Roller Coaster Tycoon 2]], which featured recreations of Six Flags parks and rides that could be expanded and operated at the player's discretion. Six Flags has approximately 18 known partners.{{Citation needed|date=November 2018}} These partners include [[Dole Food Company|Dole]], [[Armitron]], [[Mike and Ike]], [[Barcel]], [[Good Humor]], [[Nathan's Famous]], [[Coca-Cola Company|Coca-Cola]], [[Icee]], Ortega, [[Cold Stone Creamery]], [[J&J Snack Foods Corp|J&J Snack Foods]], [[Red Gold]], [[Coppertone (sunscreen)|Coppertone]], [[Johnny Rockets]], [[Samsung]], [[Dasani]], [[Mars, Incorporated|Mars]] and [[Tyson Foods]].{{Citation needed|date=November 2018}} These businesses help the park generate more income. Most importantly it provides more jobs for prospective employees. For example, Barcel USA has just expanded its partnership.{{cite web|url=http://www.sponsorship.com/IEGSR/2013/06/24/A-Sweet-Song--Barcel-USA-Expands-Six-Flags-Partner.aspx|title=A Sweet Song: Barcel USA Expands Six Flags Partnership|publisher=IEG|date=June 23, 2013|accessdate=November 3, 2018}} This helps to import food and beverages to increase sponsorships within the United States. In 2008, Six Flags partnered with [[Brash Entertainment]] to create a video game based on the Six Flags parks named ''Six Flags Fun Park''.{{cite web |title=Brash Entertainment and Six Flags Partner to Admit Gamers of All Ages to Six Flags Fun Park Videogame |url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20080605005326/en/Brash-Entertainment-Flags-Partner-Admit-Gamers-Ages |accessdate=25 November 2018 |language=en|date=2008-06-05 }} The game was first released on the [[Nintendo DS]] and [[Personal computer|PC]] in October 2008. The Wii version was delayed after Brash Entertainment went out of business and so the rights were taken over by [[Ubisoft]] and released the game on the [[Wii]] in March 2009. The game allows players to explore the themed areas and mini-games representative of a visit to a Six Flags park. In the game, players are tasked with quests that encourage them to explore the park's universe. After creating a unique custom character, Six Flags Fun Park patrons can win prizes, and compete with other players in 40 mini-games. Although the video game is called ''Six Flags Fun Park'', it lacks any major reference of Six Flags outside of the names of the different areas. This caused some to speculate that the video game was created separately, then the rights to the name of the game were sold as a way to pay for the game's development.{{Citation needed|date=June 2017}} When the game was released, it eventually ended up getting abysmal ratings across the board. [[IGN]] gave the Wii version a 4.5 out of 10, saying "The quests are uninteresting and the game's '40 Thrilling Games' (as touted by the box) are far from entertaining."{{cite web |last1=Ballard |first1=Adam |title=Six Flags Fun Park Review |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/2009/04/15/six-flags-fun-park-review-2 |website=IGN |accessdate=25 November 2018 |date=14 April 2009}} In late 2010, Six Flags began the process of removing non-Warner Bros. licensed theming from attractions. They terminated licenses with [[Thomas the Tank Engine]], [[The Wiggles]], [[Tony Hawk]], [[Evel Knievel]], and ''[[Terminator (franchise)|Terminator]]''.{{cite news|last=MacDonald|first=Brady|title=Six Flags amusement parks prepare for thematic makeovers|url=http://www.latimes.com/travel/deals/themeparks/la-trb-six-flags-retheme-20101122,0,3267615.story|accessdate=November 27, 2010|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=[[Tronc|Tribune Publishing]]|date=November 25, 2010}}{{cite news|last=MacDonald|first=Brady|title=Six Flags Magic Mountain renaming Terminator wooden coaster|url=http://www.latimes.com/travel/deals/themeparks/la-trb-terminator-apocalypse-magic-mountain-20101203,1,1983895.story|accessdate=December 3, 2010|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|publisher=Tribune Publishing|date=December 3, 2010}} However, since then there has been an expansion of licensing agreements with [[Warner Bros.]], with whom the company park has had a long-standing relationship with. The expansion lies specifically with Warner Bros. [[DC Comics]] brand, where the two teamed up to create the innovative [[Justice League: Battle for Metropolis]] as well as many other roller coasters and other rides. On May 18, 2017, Six Flags and Riverside Group signed an agreement with [[Paws, Inc.]] to use [[Garfield]] in children's areas in Six Flags-branded theme parks in China.{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20170518005768/en/Garfield-Signature-Character-Children’s-Areas-Flags-Branded-Theme|title=Garfield Signature Character Children's Areas Flags Branded Theme|publisher=Business Wire|accessdate=November 22, 2018}} ===Other assets=== On June 19, 2007, Six Flags announced it had purchased 40% of [[Dick Clark Productions]], which owns rights to ''[[American Bandstand]]'' and other shows and productions.{{cite web|url=http://investors.sixflags.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=61629&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=1016920&highlight= |title=Six Flags – Investor Relations – Financial Release |publisher=Six Flags |date=June 19, 2007 |accessdate=January 2, 2011}} In 2012, Jim Reid-Anderson stated that the company would sell its stake in [[Dick Clark Productions]]. ==Current properties== ===Amusement parks=== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:170px;"| Name ! style="width:150px;"| Location ! Owned by EPR Properties; operated by Six Flags since 2018. |- |[[Frontier City]] |[[Oklahoma City|Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]] |style="text-align:center"|1958 |style="text-align:center"|2018 |Originally owned by Six Flags during Premier Parks era. Six Flags announced on February 22, 2018 that the park would be renamed Six Flags Hurricane Harbor Concord.{{cite web|url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20180222005405/en/Concord-Water-Park-Flags-Hurricane-Harbor-Concord|title=Concord Water Park is Now Six Flags Hurricane Harbor Concord|publisher=|date=2018-02-22}} |- | [[Six Flags White Water]] | [[Marietta, Georgia]] |style="text-align:center"| 1983 |style="text-align:center"| 1999 | Located about 15 miles from Six Flags Over Georgia. |- |[[Wet'n'Wild Phoenix]] |[[Phoenix, Arizona]] |style="text-align:center"|2009 |style="text-align:center"|2018 |Owned by EPR Properties; operated by Six Flags. |- |[[Wet'n'Wild SplashTown]] |[[Spring, Texas]] |style="text-align:center"|1984 |style="text-align:center"|2018 |Owned by EPR Properties; operated by Six Flags. |- |[[White Water Bay (Oklahoma)|White Water Bay]] |[[Oklahoma City|Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]] |style="text-align:center"|1981 |style="text-align:center"|2018 |Located a short 15 miles from Frontier City, the park is owned by EPR properties and is operated by Six Flags. |- |[[Magic Waters]] |[[Cherry Valley, Illinois]] |style="text-align:center"|1984 |style="text-align:center"|2019 |Owned by Rockford Park District Board, and operated by Six Flags under a 10yr lease agreement ($425,000/yr) beginning Spring 2019. |- |} ====Indoor==== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:170px;"| Name ! style="width:150px;"| Location ! It includes a resort. |} ==Upcoming properties== ===Amusement parks=== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:170px;"| Name ! style="width:150px;"| Location ! Year Opening ! Year Acquired ! Notes ! Source |- | [[Six Flags Dubai]] | [[Dubai, U.A.E.]] |style="text-align:center"| 2019 | {{N/A}} | Located in the second phase of Dubai Parks and Resorts, it is expected to include 27 rides and attractions | {{cite web|url=https://content.sixflags.com/dubai/|title= - Six Flags Dubai -|website=content.sixflags.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/six-flags-is-coming-to-giant-dubai-amusement-park/|title=Six Flags Attractions in Dubai|work=[[CBS News]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]}} |- | [[Six Flags Zhejiang]] | [[Haiyan County, Zhejiang|Haiyan, China]] |style="text-align:center"| 2019 | {{N/A}} | First Six Flags theme park in China in partnership with Riverside Group | {{cite web |title=Six Flags and Riverside Partner with Turner to Offer New Attractions |url=http://investors.sixflags.com/news-and-events/press-releases/2018/03-22-2018-110034822 |website=investors.sixflags.com |accessdate=25 November 2018 |language=en}} |- | [[Six Flags Kids World Zhejiang]] | Haiyan, China |style="text-align:center"| 2020 | {{N/A}} | Six Flags theme park designed especially for families with young children. Located adjacent to Six Flags Zhejiang | {{cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20171026005591/en/New-Flags-Parks-Coming-China|title=Three New Six Flags Parks Coming to China|publisher=Business Wire|date=October 26, 2017|accessdate=October 27, 2017}} |- | [[Six Flags Kids World Chongqing]] | Bishan, China |style="text-align:center"| 2020 | {{N/A}} | Six Flags theme park designed especially for families with young children. Located adjacent to Six Flags Chongqing | |- | [[Six Flags Adventure Park]] | Bishan, China |style="text-align:center"| 2020 | {{N/A}} | Adjoining the Six Flags Chongqing complex | |- | [[Six Flags Chongqing]] | [[Bishan District|Bishan, China]] |style="text-align:center"| 2020 | {{N/A}} | This will be the second Six Flags-branded theme park in China. | {{cite web|url=http://investors.sixflags.com/news-and-events/press-releases/2017/02-21-2017-120106324|title=Formal Agreements Signed to Build Six Flags-Branded Parks at a Second Site in China|website=investors.sixflags.com}} |- |[[Six Flags Nanjing]] | [[Nanjing, China]] |style="text-align:center"| 2021 | {{N/A}} | This will be the third Six Flags theme park in China. | {{cite web|url=http://investors.sixflags.com/news-and-events/press-releases/2018/04-24-2018-213034885|title=Three More Six Flags Parks Coming to China|website=investors.sixflags.com}} |- |[[Six Flags Adventure Park]] |Nanjing, China |style="text-align:center"| 2021 | {{N/A}} |Adjoining the Six Flags Nanjing complex | |- |[[Six Flags Kids World Nanjing]] |Nanjing, China |style="text-align:center"| 2021 | {{N/A}} |Six Flags theme park designed especially for families with young children. 4th park announced in Six Flags Nanjing complex. Eleventh Six Flags theme park in China. |{{cite web|url=http://investors.sixflags.com/news-and-events/press-releases/2018/05-29-2018-120131700|title=Six Flags Announces 11th Park Coming to China|website=investors.sixflags.com}} |- | [[Six Flags Saudi Arabia]] | [[Riyadh, Saudi Arabia]] |style="text-align:center"| 2022 | {{N/A}} | This will be the first Six Flags-branded theme park in Saudi Arabia and the second in the [[Gulf Cooperation Council]]. | {{cite web|url=http://investors.sixflags.com/news-and-events/press-releases/2018/04-04-2018-220015471|title=International Expansion Continues with Six Flags-Branded Park in Saudi Arabia|website=investors.sixflags.com}} |} ===Water parks=== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:170px;"| Name ! style="width:150px;"| Location ! Year Opening ! Year Acquired ! Notes ! Source |- | [[Six Flags Hurricane Harbor]] Zhejiang | [[Haiyan County, Zhejiang|Haiyan, China]] |style="text-align:center"| 2019 | {{N/A}} | Located within Six Flags Zhejiang | {{cite web|url=http://www.inparkmagazine.com/six-flags-waterpark-gm-zhejiang/|title=Six Flags Announces Waterpark and General Manager for First China Property|publisher=}} |- |Six Flags Hurricane Harbor Nanjing |Nanjing, China |style="text-align:center"| 2021 | {{N/A}} |Part of four park Six Flags Nanjing complex | |} == Former properties == ''These properties are listed in alphabetical order by the final name of the park while under Six Flags control.'' {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:98%;" |- ! style="width:200px;"|Park ! style="width:160px;"|Location ! style="width:80px;"|Year opened ! style="width:80px;"|Year closed/Sold ! |Notes |- | [[American Adventures]] | [[Marietta, Georgia]] |style="text-align:center"| 1990 |style="text-align:center"| 2008 | This park was located adjacent to Six Flags White Water, and was marketed to families with young children. It was acquired by Zuma Holdings in 2008 and permanently closed in 2010. |- | [[Bellewaerde]] | [[Ypres]], Belgium |style="text-align:center"| 1954 |style="text-align:center"| 2004 | This park was acquired in 1998. The property was sold and remains in operation under another company. |- | [[Movieland Wax Museum]] | [[Buena Park, California]] |style="text-align:center"| 1962 |style="text-align:center"| 1985 | Purchased in 1970, this [[wax museum]] sold all of its holdings and moved many of the sets and wax figures to California, but sold the original clothing and props to the American Musical Academy of Arts Association. It was eventually closed in 2005. |- | [[Six Flags AstroWorld]] | [[Houston|Houston, Texas]] |style="text-align:center"| 1968 |style="text-align:center"| 2005 | AstroWorld was acquired in 1974. The park closed on October 30, 2005 and was demolished between late 2005 and 2006 for other development. |- | [[Six Flags Atlantis]] | [[Hollywood, Florida]] |style="text-align:center"| 1982 |style="text-align:center"| 1989 | This water park was acquired in 1984. Property was sold, but was eventually demolished in 1994. |- | [[AutoWorld (theme park)|Six Flags AutoWorld]] | [[Flint, Michigan]] |style="text-align:center"| 1984 |style="text-align:center"| 1985 | This indoor entertainment venue was eventually closed and the facility demolished. |- | [[Walibi Belgium|Six Flags Belgium]] | [[Wavre]], Belgium |style="text-align:center"| 1975 |style="text-align:center"| 2004 | The Walibi properties were purchased in 1998. Renamed Six Flags Belgium in 2000. Sold to [[Compagnie des Alpes|CDA Parks]] in 2004. The park remains open today under the name Walibi Belgium. |- | [[Elitch Gardens Theme Park|Six Flags Elitch Gardens]] | [[Denver|Denver, Colorado]] |style="text-align:center"| 1890 |style="text-align:center"| 2007 | This park was owned by Premier Parks when it purchased the Six Flags chain. It was sold to [[PARC Management]] in the 2007 property sell-off. |- | [[Walibi Holland|Six Flags Holland]] | [[Biddinghuizen]], Netherlands |style="text-align:center"| 1971 |style="text-align:center"| 2004 | Like the other Walibi properties, the former Walibi Flevo was purchased in 1998. Renamed Six Flags Holland in 2000. Sold to [[Compagnie des Alpes|CDA Parks]] in 2004. It remains open today under the name Walibi Holland. |- | [[Kentucky Kingdom|Six Flags Kentucky Kingdom]] | [[Louisville, Kentucky]] |style="text-align:center"| 1987 |style="text-align:center"| 2010 | Initially built by local investors. This park includes Six Flags Splashwater Kingdom water park, which opened in 1992. In February 2010, Six Flags announced it would close the park due to a dispute with the [[Kentucky State Fair|Kentucky State Fair Board]], from which Six Flags leased much of the park's land area and attractions. In 2014, Kentucky Kingdom reopened under new management. |- | [[Six Flags New Orleans]] | [[New Orleans]] |style="text-align:center"| 2000 |style="text-align:center"| 2005 | Originally opened as Jazzland, this park was bought in 2002 and re-branded as Six Flags New Orleans in 2003. It was closed after severe damage from [[Hurricane Katrina]] in 2005. The city of New Orleans sued Six Flags in 2009 for not making progress to re-open and for not making required lease payments;{{cite news|title=N.O. plans to sue Six Flags |url=http://www.wwltv.com/news/local/65292407.html |accessdate=November 14, 2011 |newspaper=WWL-TV |publisher=Tegna Inc. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120118163928/http://www.wwltv.com/news/local/65292407.html |archivedate=January 18, 2012 |df=mdy }} ultimately, the site was turned over to the city along with a cash payment.{{cite news|title=City now owns Six Flags |url=http://www.abc26.com/news/local/wgno_news_sixflagsdeal,0,7593285.story |accessdate=November 14, 2011 |newspaper=WGNO-TV |publisher=Tribune Broadcasting|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120404220116/http://www.abc26.com/news/local/wgno_news_sixflagsdeal%2C0%2C7593285.story |archivedate=April 4, 2012 |df=mdy }} In 2011, the city made plans to auction the site and all remaining rides and equipment.{{cite news|title=Who wants Six Flags?|url=http://www.fox8live.com/news/local/story/Who-wants-Six-Flags/rsUqrIha6UGWbm-Ezjy_vw.cspx|accessdate=November 14, 2011|newspaper=WVUE-TV|publisher=Raycom Media}} |- | [[Six Flags Power Plant]] | [[Baltimore]] |style="text-align:center"| 1985 |style="text-align:center"| 1989 | Located in the [[Inner Harbor]] district of Baltimore, the site of this indoor amusement park has been redeveloped with [[Hard Rock Cafe]], [[Barnes & Noble]], [[Gold's Gym]] (closed 2010), and the world's first [[ESPN Zone]] location (closed 2010). This was Six Flags' second attempt at an indoor amusement park after AutoWorld. It was a little more successful, but it too closed down eventually. |- | Six Flags Stars Hall of Fame | [[Orlando, Florida]] |style="text-align:center"| 1975 |style="text-align:center"| 1984 | This wax museum was located near [[SeaWorld Orlando]]. Like SeaWorld, it was acquired by [[Harcourt Brace Jovanovich]], but it was closed almost immediately after the sale. |- | [[Six Flags Waterworld]] | [[Houston|Houston, Texas]] |style="text-align:center"| 1983 |style="text-align:center"| 2005 | This water park was adjacent to Six Flags AstroWorld. Park was sold and demolished for other development. |- | [[Geauga Lake|Six Flags Worlds of Adventure]] | [[Aurora, Ohio]] |style="text-align:center"| 1887 |style="text-align:center"| 2004 | Geauga Lake park was purchased by Premier Parks in 1995 prior to its purchase of the entire Six Flags chain. Re-branded as Six Flags Ohio for its opening season in 2000. It was then renamed Six Flags Worlds of Adventure when Six Flags annexed the adjacent [[SeaWorld Ohio]] marine park in 2001. In 2004, the entire property was sold to competing amusement park operator [[Cedar Fair]]. The park was closed after the 2007 season, but the attached water park remained open until the end of the 2016 season. |- | [[Movie Park Germany|Warner Bros. Movie World Germany]] | [[Bottrop]], Germany |style="text-align:center"| 1967 |style="text-align:center"| 2004 | This park was purchased in 1998. It was sold, with most of the other European parks, in the same transaction in 2004, and being renamed as Movie Park Germany. |- | [[Parque Warner Madrid|Warner Bros. Movie World Madrid]] | [[Madrid|Madrid, Spain]] |style="text-align:center"| 2002 |style="text-align:center"| 2004 | This park was built in a joint venture, to be managed by Six Flags. Unlike the other European Six Flags parks, this one was sold back to Time Warner, and currently operates under the name Parque Warner Madrid. |- | Walibi Aquitaine | [[Bordeaux]], France |style="text-align:center"| 1992 |style="text-align:center"| 2004 | The Walibi properties were purchased in 1998. The park remains open today under new management, and under the name Walibi Sud-Ouest. |- | [[Walygator Parc|Walibi Lorraine]] | [[Metz]], France |style="text-align:center"| 1989 |style="text-align:center"| 2004 | The Walibi properties were purchased in 1998. The park remains open today under the name Walygator Parc. |- | [[Walibi Rhône-Alpes]] | [[Lyon]], France |style="text-align:center"| 1979 |style="text-align:center"| 2004 | The Walibi properties were purchased in 1998. The park remains open today under new management. |- | [[Wild Waves and Enchanted Village]] | [[Federal Way, Washington]] |style="text-align:center"| 1977 |style="text-align:center"| 2007 | This combination water park and amusement park was sold in 2007, and remains open to this day. |- | [[Zoombezi Bay|Wyandot Lake]] | [[Columbus, Ohio]] |style="text-align:center"| 1896 |style="text-align:center"| 2006 | The property was sold to the adjacent [[Columbus Zoo and Aquarium]] in 2006. The park reopened under zoo management on May 26, 2008 as [[Zoombezi Bay]]. |} ==See also== {{portal|Six Flags}} *[[Incidents at Six Flags parks]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons category|Six Flags amusement parks}} * {{Official website|https://www.sixflags.com/}} {{Six Flags}} [[Category:Six Flags| ]] [[Category:Amusement park companies]] [[Category:Entertainment companies of the United States]] [[Category:Companies based in the Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex]] [[Category:Entertainment companies established in 1962]] [[Category:Former Time Warner subsidiaries]] [[Category:Companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange]] [[Category:Companies that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in 2009]]
